Divisors and Vanishing Theorems

Assjock
Algebraic GeometryBirational Geometry Algebraic Geometry Birational Geometry

发布于：Jul 26, 2025

31.1k words

194 min

双有理几何基础之linear system 上的positivity 以及 Kodaira vanishing theorem 的推论们. 全文抄写自Lazarsfeld 的Positivity in Algebraic Geometry, 不含任何一点原创. 属于是假期闲着无聊想了解下Minimal Model Program 时的一些前置知识. 最重要的部分还是最后一节关于一些有效消失定理们.

All schemes are assumed to be over C\mathbb{C}C.

Some Homological Algebra

We first recall some basic facts in homological algebra:

Let XXX be a variety, F∙\mathcal{F}^{\bullet}F∙ be the complex of coherent OX\mathcal{O}_{X}OX​-module. The cohomology is defined by Hi(F∙)=kerdiimdi−1\mathcal{H}^{i}(\mathcal{F}^{\bullet})=\frac{\mathop{\mathrm{ker}}d_{i}}{\mathop{\mathrm{im}}d_{i-1}}Hi(F∙)=imdi−1​kerdi​​, where ddd is the differential.

A spectral sequence is a colletion of data: (Erp,q,En)(E_{r}^{p,q}, E^{n})(Erp,q​,En) and differential drp,q:Erp,q→Erp+r,q−r+1d_{r}^{p,q}:E_{r}^{p,q}\to E_{r}^{p+r,q-r+1}drp,q​:Erp,q​→Erp+r,q−r+1​ such that drp+r,q−r+1∘drp,q=0d_{r}^{p+r,q-r+1}\circ d_{r}^{p,q}=0drp+r,q−r+1​∘drp,q​=0. So drd_{r}dr​ actually defines complexes. Moreover, we require Er+1p,q=H0(Erp+∙r,q−∙r+1)E_{r+1}^{p,q}=H^{0}(E_{r}^{p+\bullet r,q-\bullet r+1})Er+1p,q​=H0(Erp+∙r,q−∙r+1​). For fixed p,qp,qp,q, if there is a number r0r_{0}r0​ such that drp,q=drp−r,q+r−1d_{r}^{p,q}=d_{r}^{p-r,q+r-1}drp,q​=drp−r,q+r−1​ for all r≥r0r\geq r_{0}r≥r0​, then the Erp,qE_{r}^{p,q}Erp,q​ finally stabilizes, we say E∞p,q=Erp,qE_{\infty}^{p,q}=E_{r}^{p,q}E∞p,q​=Erp,q​ the limiting term. There exists a decreasing filtration ⋯Fp+1En⊆FpEn⊆⋯⊆En\cdots F^{p+1}E^{n}\subseteq F^{p}E^{n}\subseteq \cdots\subseteq E^{n}⋯Fp+1En⊆FpEn⊆⋯⊆En (in the context we may assume ∩FpEn=0\cap F^{p}E^{n}=0∩FpEn=0 and ∪FpEn=En\cup F^{p}E^{n}=E^{n}∪FpEn=En) such that E∞p,q=FpEp+q/Fp+1Ep+qE_{\infty}^{p,q}=F^{p}E^{p+q} /F^{p+1}E^{p+q}E∞p,q​=FpEp+q/Fp+1Ep+q. Write

Erp,q⇒Ep+q.E_{r}^{p,q}\Rightarrow E^{p+q}. Erp,q​⇒Ep+q.

A filtered complex (C∙,d)(C^{\bullet}, d)(C∙,d) is a collection of subobjects FpCqF^{p}C^{q}FpCq such that Fp+qCq⊆FpCq+1F^{p+q}C^{q}\subseteq F^{p}C^{q+1}Fp+qCq⊆FpCq+1 and dFpCq⊆FpCq+1dF^{p}C^{q}\subseteq F^{p}C^{q+1}dFpCq⊆FpCq+1 (n the context we may assume ∩FpCq=0\cap F^{p}C^{q}=0∩FpCq=0 and ∪FpCq=Cq\cup F^{p}C^{q}=C^{q}∪FpCq=Cq). Let

Zrp,q=d−1(Fp+rCp+q+1)∩FpCp+qd−1(Fp+rCp+q+1)∩Fp+1Cp+q;Z_{r}^{p,q}=\frac{d^{-1}(F^{p+r}C^{p+q+1})\cap F^{p}C^{p+q}}{d^{-1}(F^{p+r}C^{p+q+1})\cap F^{p+1}C^{p+q}}; Zrp,q​=d−1(Fp+rCp+q+1)∩Fp+1Cp+qd−1(Fp+rCp+q+1)∩FpCp+q​;

Brp,q=d(Fp−r+1Cp+q−1)∩FpCp+qd(Fp−r+qCp+q)∩Fp+qCp+q,B_{r}^{p,q}=\frac{d(F^{p-r+1}C^{p+q-1})\cap F^{p}C^{p+q}}{d(F^{p-r+q}C^{p+q})\cap F^{p+q}C^{p+q}}, Brp,q​=d(Fp−r+qCp+q)∩Fp+qCp+qd(Fp−r+1Cp+q−1)∩FpCp+q​,

Erp,q=Zrp,qBrp,q.E_{r}^{p,q}=\frac{Z_{r}^{p,q}}{B_{r}^{p,q}}. Erp,q​=Brp,q​Zrp,q​​.

The differential is given by

Erp,q→Zrp,qZr−1p,q→∼Br+1p+r,q−r+1Brp+r,q−r+1↪Erp+r,q−r+1,E_{r}^{p,q}\to \frac{Z_{r}^{p,q}}{Z_{r-1}^{p,q}}\xrightarrow{\sim} \frac{B_{r+1}^{p+r,q-r+1}}{B_{r}^{p+r,q-r+1}}\hookrightarrow E_{r}^{p+r,q-r+1}, Erp,q​→Zr−1p,q​Zrp,q​​∼​Brp+r,q−r+1​Br+1p+r,q−r+1​​↪Erp+r,q−r+1​,

then Erp,qE_{r}^{p,q}Erp,q​ forms a spectral sequence. The objects E0p,q=FpCp+1/Fp+1Cp+qE_{0}^{p,q}=F^{p}C^{p+1}/F^{p+1}C^{p+q}E0p,q​=FpCp+1/Fp+1Cp+q and

E1p,q=hp+q(grpC∙)⇒hp+q(C∙).E_{1}^{p,q}=h^{p+q}(gr^{p}C^{\bullet})\Rightarrow h^{p+q}(C^{\bullet}). E1p,q​=hp+q(grpC∙)⇒hp+q(C∙).

For a double complex we mean (C∙,∙,dh,dv)(C^{\bullet,\bullet}, d_{h},d_{v})(C∙,∙,dh​,dv​) such that dh2=dv2=0d_{h}^{2}=d_{v}^{2}=0dh2​=dv2​=0 andn dhdv+dvdh=0d_{h}d_{v}+d_{v}d_{h}=0dh​dv​+dv​dh​=0. The total complex associated to C∙,∙C^{\bullet,\bullet}C∙,∙ is

Tot(C)n=⨁p+q=nCp,qTot(C)^{n}=\bigoplus_{p+q=n}C^{p,q} Tot(C)n=p+q=n⨁​Cp,q

with differential d=dh+dvd=d_{h}+d_{v}d=dh​+dv​. Then we can define filtered complex by FpCp+q=⨁r≥pCp+q−r,rF^{p}C^{p+q}=\bigoplus_{r\geq p}C^{p+q-r,r}FpCp+q=⨁r≥p​Cp+q−r,r. Define the spectral sequence associated to C∙,∙C^{\bullet, \bullet}C∙,∙ with E0p,q=Cq,pE_{0}^{p,q}=C^{q,p}E0p,q​=Cq,p, d0=dvd_{0}=d_{v}d0​=dv​, E1p,q=Hvq(C∙,p)E_{1}^{p,q}=H_{v}^{q}(C^{\bullet,p})E1p,q​=Hvq​(C∙,p) and d1d_{1}d1​ is induced by dhd_{h}dh​, E2p,q=Hhp(Hvq(C∙,∙))E_{2}^{p,q}=H_{h}^{p}(H_{v}^{q}(C^{\bullet,\bullet}))E2p,q​=Hhp​(Hvq​(C∙,∙)). Then

E2p,q=Hhp(Hvq(C∙,∙))⇒Hp+q(Tot(C)).E_{2}^{p,q}=H_{h}^{p}(H_{v}^{q}(C^{\bullet,\bullet}))\Rightarrow H^{p+q}(Tot(C)). E2p,q​=Hhp​(Hvq​(C∙,∙))⇒Hp+q(Tot(C)).

The Cartan-Eilenberg resolution of A∙A^{\bullet}A∙ is a double complex C∙,∙C^{\bullet,\bullet}C∙,∙ such that Ap→Cp,∙A^{p}\to C^{p,\bullet}Ap→Cp,∙, ker(Ap→Ap+1)→ker(Cp,∙→Cp+1,∙)\mathop{\mathrm{ker}}(A^{p}\to A^{p+1})\to \mathop{\mathrm{ker}}(C^{p,\bullet}\to C^{p+1,\bullet})ker(Ap→Ap+1)→ker(Cp,∙→Cp+1,∙), im(Ap→Ap+1)→im(Cp,∙→Cp+1,bullet)\mathop{\mathrm{im}}(A^{p}\to A^{p+1})\to \mathop{\mathrm{im}}(C^{p,\bullet}\to C^{p+1,bullet})im(Ap→Ap+1)→im(Cp,∙→Cp+1,bullet) and Hp(A∙)→Hhp(C∙,∙)H^{p}(A^{\bullet})\to H_{h}^{p}(C^{\bullet, \bullet})Hp(A∙)→Hhp​(C∙,∙) give injective resolutions. Moreover, we sometimes require 0→kerdhi,j→Ci,j→imdhi,j→00\to \mathop{\mathrm{ker}}d_{h}^{i,j}\to C^{i,j}\to \mathop{\mathrm{im}}d_{h}^{i,j}\to 00→kerdhi,j​→Ci,j→imdhi,j​→0 splits.

Every complex admits a Cartan-Eilenberg resolution. Using this, we can show

Theorem 1 (Grothendieck Spectral Sequence). Consider A\mathcal{A}A, B\mathcal{B}B, C\mathcal{C}C which all all category of abelian sheaves on some projective variety. F:A→BF:\mathcal{A}\to \mathcal{B}F:A→B and G:B→CG:\mathcal{B}\to \mathcal{C}G:B→C are all additive functors such that FFF maps injective elements into GGG-acyclic part. Then there is a spectral sequence Erp,qE_{r}^{p,q}Erp,q​ such that

E2p,q=RpG(RqF(A))⇒Rp+q(F∘G)(A).E_{2}^{p,q}=R^{p}G(R^{q}F(A))\Rightarrow R^{p+q}(F\circ G)(A). E2p,q​=RpG(RqF(A))⇒Rp+q(F∘G)(A).

Divisors, line bundles and linear systems

Definition 2 (Cartier Divisor). A Cartier divisor on XXX is a global section of the sheaf KX∗/OX∗\mathcal{K}_{X}^{*} /\mathcal{O}_{X}^{*}KX∗​/OX∗​, where KX\mathcal{K}_{X}KX​ of the total quotients. Denote the divisor group by

Div(X)=H0(KX∗/OX∗).Div(X)=H^{0}(\mathcal{K}_{X}^{*}/\mathcal{O}_{X}^{*}). Div(X)=H0(KX∗​/OX∗​).

We represent a Cartier divisor by {(Ui,fi)}\{(U_{i},f_{i})\}{(Ui​,fi​)} where fi∈H0(Ui,KX∗)f_{i}\in H^{0}(U_{i}, \mathcal{K}_{X}^{*})fi​∈H0(Ui​,KX∗​) and satisfies the cocycle condition fi=gijfjf_{i}=g_{ij}f_{j}fi​=gij​fj​, gij∈H0(Ui∩Uj,OX∗)g_{ij}\in H^{0}(U_{i}\cap U_{j}, \mathcal{O}_{X}^{*})gij​∈H0(Ui​∩Uj​,OX∗​).

Remark 3. The support of divisor D={(Ui,fi)}D=\{(U_{i}, f_{i})\}D={(Ui​,fi​)} is the set

Supp(D)={x∈X∣xi∈Ui and fi is not unit in OX,x}.\mathop{\mathrm{Supp}}(D)=\{x\in X|x_{i}\in U_{i} \text{ and } f_{i} \text{ is not unit in }\mathcal{O}_{X,x}\}. Supp(D)={x∈X∣xi​∈Ui​ and fi​ is not unit in OX,x​}.

If we regard DDD as an Weil divisor D=∑ai[Di]D=\sum a_{i}[D_{i}]D=∑ai​[Di​], the support Supp(D)=∐ai≠0∣Di∣\mathop{\mathrm{Supp}}(D)=\coprod_{a_{i}\neq 0}\left| D_{i} \right|Supp(D)=∐ai​=0​∣Di​∣.

Definition 4. A kkk-cycle on variety XXX is a Z\mathbb{Z}Z-linear combination of irreducible subvariety of dimension kkk. We denote the group of all kkk-cycles by Zk(X)Z_{k}(X)Zk​(X).

For further definition of property of divisors, e.g. linear equivalence and effective divisors e.t.c. we refer to Hartshorne.

Example 5. For a morphism f:Y→Xf:Y\to Xf:Y→X between schemes, define f∗Df^{*}Df∗D by the pullback of all local section {f−1Ui,f∗fi}\{f^{-1}U_{i}, f^{*}f_{i}\}{f−1Ui​,f∗fi​}. To make {f−1Ui,f∗fi}\{f^{-1}U_{i}, f^{*}f_{i}\}{f−1Ui​,f∗fi​} really define a Cartier divisor, the section must be nontrivial, which is true if we assume ∃y∈Y\exists y\in Y∃y∈Y such that f(y)∉Supp(D)f(y)\notin Supp(D)f(y)∈/Supp(D). (Note here we can assume DDD effective and fi∈H0(Ui,OUi∗)f_{i}\in H^{0}(U_{i},\mathcal{O}_{U_{i}}^{*})fi​∈H0(Ui​,OUi​∗​), and use linear extension to all divisors.) If YYY is reduced, the requirement is just that no components of YYY map into the support of DDD.

Definition 6 (Canonical Divisor). Let XXX be a nonsingular complete variety of dimension nnn. Denote ωX=∧nΩX\omega_{X}=\wedge^{n}\Omega_{X}ωX​=∧nΩX​ to be the canonical bundle on XXX, and by KXK_{X}KX​ we denote the canonical divisor. Then O(KX)=ωX\mathcal{O}(K_{X})=\omega_{X}O(KX​)=ωX​.

Definition 7. Let L\mathcal{L}L be a line bundle, V⊆H0(X,L)V\subseteq H^{0}(X,\mathcal{L})V⊆H0(X,L) is a finite dimensional subspace. Denote ∣V∣=P(V)\left| V \right| =\mathbb{P}(V)∣V∣=P(V) be the projective space of one dimensional subspace of VVV. We say ∣V∣\left| V \right|∣V∣ is complete if V=H0(X,L)V=H^{0}(X,\mathcal{L})V=H0(X,L).

Definition 8. Let eval:V⊗OX→Leval:V\otimes \mathcal{O}_{X}\to\mathcal{L}eval:V⊗OX​→L be the evaluation map. Let b(∣V∣)\mathfrak{b}(\left| V \right| )b(∣V∣) be the image of V⊗L∗→OXV\otimes \mathcal{L}^{*}\to \mathcal{O}_{X}V⊗L∗→OX​ given by the evalevaleval. The base point is the locus cutting down by the ideal b(∣V∣)\mathfrak{b}(\left| V \right|)b(∣V∣), denoted by Bs(∣V∣)Bs(\left| V \right|)Bs(∣V∣). We say L\mathcal{L}L is base point free if Bs(∣V∣)=∅Bs(\left| V \right| )=\varnothingBs(∣V∣)=∅.

Example 9. Assume XXX is projective variety, DDD is a divisor on XXX, then for m,n≥1m,n\geq 1m,n≥1, the natural homomorphism

H0(O(mD))⊗H0(O(nD))→H0(O((m+n)D))H^{0}(\mathcal{O}(mD))\otimes H^{0}(\mathcal{O}(nD))\to H^{0}(\mathcal{O}((m+n)D)) H0(O(mD))⊗H0(O(nD))→H0(O((m+n)D))

defines inclusion b(∣mD∣)⋅b(∣nD∣)⊆b(∣(m+n)D∣)\mathfrak{b}(\left| mD \right| )\cdot \mathfrak{b}(\left| nD \right|) \subseteq \mathfrak{b}(\left| (m+n)D \right| )b(∣mD∣)⋅b(∣nD∣)⊆b(∣(m+n)D∣).

Example 10. The linear system ∣V∣\left| V \right|∣V∣ defines a morphsm

φ:X−Bs(∣V∣)→P(∣V∣),\varphi:X-Bs(\left| V \right| ) \to \mathbb{P}(\left| V \right| ), φ:X−Bs(∣V∣)→P(∣V∣),

defined by

φ:x↦(s1(x):⋯:sn(x)),\varphi:x\mapsto (s_{1}(x):\cdots: s_{n}(x)), φ:x↦(s1​(x):⋯:sn​(x)),

where s1,…,sns_{1},\dots, s_{n}s1​,…,sn​ is a set of basis of VVV.

Note if we choose different basis of VVV, then the corresponding morphism will differ by an automorphism of P(V)\mathbb{P}(V)P(V). If ∣V∣\left| V \right|∣V∣ is base point free then φ\varphiφ defines a morphism X→PnX\to \mathbb{P}^{n}X→Pn.

Example 11. Suppose W⊆VW\subseteq VW⊆V is a subspace, then Bs(∣V∣)⊆Bs(∣W∣)Bs(\left| V \right| )\subseteq Bs(\left| W \right| )Bs(∣V∣)⊆Bs(∣W∣) and on X−Bs(∣W∣)X-Bs(\left| W \right| )X−Bs(∣W∣), the morphism φW=π∘φV\varphi_{W}=\pi\circ \varphi_{V}φW​=π∘φV​, where π:P(V)−P(V/W)→P(W)\pi:\mathbb{P}(V)-\mathbb{P}(V /W)\to \mathbb{P}(W)π:P(V)−P(V/W)→P(W) is the linear projection.

Definition 12. We say two Cartier divisors D1,D2∈Div(X)D_{1}, D_{2}\in Div(X)D1​,D2​∈Div(X) are numberical equivalent if D1⋅C=D2⋅CD_{1}\cdot C=D_{2}\cdot CD1​⋅C=D2​⋅C for every irreducible curve C⊆XC\subseteq XC⊆X. A divisor DDD is called numerically trivial if it is numerical equivalent to zero.

Definition 13. Denote the set of all numerically trivial divisor by Num(X)Num(X)Num(X). The Neron Severi group of XXX is defined by N1(X)=Div(X)/Num(X)N^{1}(X)=Div(X) /Num(X)N1(X)=Div(X)/Num(X).

Remark 14. This definition is slightly different with general definition, which is Pic(X)/Pic0(X)Pic(X) /Pic^{0}(X)Pic(X)/Pic0(X). Using intersection theory on Picard scheme one can prove that they are the same with respect to Z,Q,R\mathbb{Z}, \mathbb{Q},\mathbb{R}Z,Q,R coefficients.

Theorem 15. Neron Severi group is torsion free group of finite rank. Its rank is called Picard number and denoted by ρ(X)\rho(X)ρ(X).

Proof

Proof. Recall the intersection number D⋅CD\cdot CD⋅C is given by ∫Cc1(O(D))\int_{C}c_{1}(\mathcal{O}(D))∫C​c1​(O(D)). Then divisors with trivial first chern class are in Num(X)Num(X)Num(X). Consider the φ:Div(X)→H2(X,Z)\varphi:Div(X)\to H^{2}(X,\mathbb{Z})φ:Div(X)→H2(X,Z) arising from the exponential sequence and Div(X)→Pic(X)Div(X)\to \mathop{\mathrm{Pic}}(X)Div(X)→Pic(X). Then kerφ⊆Num(X)\mathop{\mathrm{ker}}\varphi\subseteq Num(X)kerφ⊆Num(X) and therefore N1(X)N^{1}(X)N1(X) is the quotient of imφ\mathop{\mathrm{im}}\varphiimφ by some subgroup, which is evidently finite generated and torsion free. ◻

From above proof we also see the intersection number only depends on numerical equivalence, i.e. for D1i≡numD2jD_{1}^{i}\equiv_{num}D_{2}^{j}D1i​≡num​D2j​, D11⋯D1dim⁡X−dim⁡V⋅V=D21⋯D2dim⁡X−dim⁡V⋅VD_{1}^{1}\cdots D_{1}^{\dim X-\dim V}\cdot V=D_{2}^{1}\cdots D_{2}^{\dim X-\dim V}\cdot VD11​⋯D1dimX−dimV​⋅V=D21​⋯D2dimX−dimV​⋅V.

Definition 16 (Rank of coherent sheaf). Let XXX be variety of dimension nnn, F\mathcal{F}F is coherent sheaf on XXX. The rank rk(F)\mathop{\mathrm{rk}}(\mathcal{F})rk(F) is defined to be lengthOX,ξFξlength_{\mathcal{O}_{X,\xi}}\mathcal{F}_{\xi}lengthOX,ξ​​Fξ​, where ξ\xiξ is the generic point of XXX.

Theorem 17 (Asymptotic Riemann Roch). Let XXX be projective variety of dimension nnn. DDD is a divisor on XXX, then χ(O(mD))\chi(\mathcal{O}(mD))χ(O(mD)) is a polynomial of degree ≤n\leq n≤n.

χ(O(mD))=Dnn!mn+O(mn−1).\chi(\mathcal{O}(mD))=\frac{D^{n}}{n!}m^{n}+O(m^{n-1}). χ(O(mD))=n!Dn​mn+O(mn−1).

More generally, for coherent sheaf F\mathcal{F}F on XXX,

χ(F(mD))=rk(F)Dnn!mn+O(mn−1).\chi(\mathcal{F}(mD))=\mathop{\mathrm{rk}}(\mathcal{F})\frac{D^{n}}{n!}m^{n}+O(m^{n-1}). χ(F(mD))=rk(F)n!Dn​mn+O(mn−1).

Proof

Proof. This is direct corollary of Hirzebruch Riemann Roch Theorem. ◻

Proposition 18. Let XXX be a projective variety of dimension nnn. Let DDD be a divisor on XXX with the property that
hi(O(mD))=O(mn−1)h^{i}(\mathcal{O}(mD))=O(m^{n-1})hi(O(mD))=O(mn−1) for i>0i>0i>0. Fix a positive rational number α\alphaα with 0<αn<Dn0<\alpha^{n}<D^{n}0<αn<Dn. Then for m≫0m\gg 0m≫0, there exists for any smooth point x∈Xx\in Xx∈X a divisor E=Ex∈∣mD∣E=E_{x}\in \left| mD \right|E=Ex​∈∣mD∣ with multx(D)>mαmult_{x}(D)>m\alphamultx​(D)>mα.

Proof

Proof. Omitted. ◻

Amplitude

Definition 19. Let XXX be a proper scheme, L\mathcal{L}L is a line bundle on XXX,

  1. L\mathcal{L}L is very ample if the corresponding morphism φ:X→Pn\varphi:X\to \mathbb{P}^{n}φ:X→Pn is closed immersion, and then L=φ∗OPn(1)\mathcal{L}=\varphi^{*}\mathcal{O}_{\mathbb{P}^{n}}(1)L=φ∗OPn​(1).

  2. L\mathcal{L}L is ample if Lm\mathcal{L}^{m}Lm is very ample for some m>0m>0m>0.

Note this definition applys for proper scheme, therefore every immersion X→PnX\to \mathbb{P}^{n}X→Pn has closed image, and thus a closed immersion. The definition here is compactible with definition in Hartshorne.

Example 20. If D1,…,DnD_{1},\dots, D_{n}D1​,…,Dn​ are ample divisors on dimension nnn scheme XXX, then miDim_{i}D_{i}mi​Di​ are very ample for some mi>0m_{i}>0mi​>0. Then

m1D1⋯mnDn=m1f∗H1⋯mnf∗Hn=deg⁡φ∏i=1nmiHi>0,m_{1}D_{1}\cdots m_{n}D_{n}=m_{1}f^{*}H_{1}\cdots m_{n}f^{*}H_{n}=\deg \varphi \prod_{i=1}^{n}m_{i}H_{i}>0, m1​D1​⋯mn​Dn​=m1​f∗H1​⋯mn​f∗Hn​=degφi=1∏n​mi​Hi​>0,

and thus D1⋯Dn>0D_{1}\cdots D_{n}>0D1​⋯Dn​>0.

Theorem 21. Let L\mathcal{L}L be a line bundle on proper scheme XXX. Then the followings are equivalent:

  1. L\mathcal{L}L is ample;

  2. For any coherent sheaf F\mathcal{F}F on XXX, there exists positive number m1=m1(F)m_{1}=m_{1}(\mathcal{F})m1​=m1​(F) such that Hi(F⊗Lm)=0H^{i}(\mathcal{F}\otimes \mathcal{L}^{m})=0Hi(F⊗Lm)=0 for all m≥m1m\geq m_{1}m≥m1​;

  3. For any coherent sheaf F\mathcal{F}F on XXX, there exists positive number m2=m2(F)m_{2}=m_{2}(\mathcal{F})m2​=m2​(F) such that F⊗Lm\mathcal{F}\otimes \mathcal{L}^{m}F⊗Lm is generated by global sections for all m≥m2m\geq m_{2}m≥m2​;

There exists a positive integer m3>0m_{3}>0m3​>0 such that Lm\mathcal{L}^{m}Lm is very ample for all m≥m3m\geq m_{3}m≥m3​.

Proof

Proof. See Hartshorne III 5.3 and II 7.5. ◻

Example 22. For L\mathcal{L}L a globally generated line bundle on a proper scheme XXX, the set

U={y∈X∣L⊗my is globally generated}U=\{y\in X|\mathcal{L}\otimes m_{y}\text{ is globally generated}\} U={y∈X∣L⊗my​ is globally generated}

is open.

Example 23. If DDD is ample divisor on XXX and EEE is any divisor, then mD+EmD+EmD+E is very ample for m≫0m\gg 0m≫0. This is an easy corollary of the fact that tensor product of globally generated sheaves is still globally generated.

we know Hj(X,NiF⊗Lm)=0H^{j}(X,\mathcal{N}^{i}\mathcal{F}\otimes \mathcal{L}^{m})=0Hj(X,NiF⊗Lm)=0 for all j>0j>0j>0 and m≫0m\gg 0m≫0. ◻

Definition 32 (Relative Amplitude). Let f:X→Tf:X\to Tf:X→T be a proper morphism of schemes, let L\mathcal{L}L be a line bundle on XXX,

  1. L\mathcal{L}L is very ample relative to fff if the canonical map ρ:f∗f∗L→L\rho: f^{*}f_{*}\mathcal{L}\to \mathcal{L}ρ:f∗f∗​L→L is surjective and defines an immersion

  1. L\mathcal{L}L is ample relative to fff if Lm\mathcal{L}^{m}Lm is very ample for some m>0m>0m>0.

Clearly relative ampleness is local on the target.

Theorem 36. Let f:X→Tf:X\to Tf:X→T be a proper morphism of schemes. L\mathcal{L}L is a line bundle on XXX. Then L\mathcal{L}L is fff-ample if and only if Lt\mathcal{L}_{t}Lt​ is ample on XtX_{t}Xt​ for every t∈Tt\in Tt∈T.

Theorem 37 (Nakai-Moishezon-Kleiman criterion). Let L\mathcal{L}L be a line bundle on a projective scheme XXX. Then L\mathcal{L}L is ample if and only if $$\int_{V} c_{1}(L)^{\dim(V)} > 0$$ for every positive-dimensional irreducible subvariety V⊆XV\subseteq XV⊆X (including the irreducible components of XXX).

Proof

Proof. If we have L\mathcal{L}L ample, then Lm\mathcal{L}^{m}Lm is very ample, therefore

mdim⁡V∫Vc1(L)dim⁡V=∫Vc1(Lm)dim⁡V>0.m^{\dim V}\int_{V}c_{1}(\mathcal{L})^{\dim V}=\int_{V}c_{1}(\mathcal{L}^{m})^{\dim V}>0.mdimV∫V​c1​(L)dimV=∫V​c1​(Lm)dimV>0.

Conversely, assume the positivity of intersection numbers. We may assume XXX is reduced and irreducible. We may apply the induction on dimension. For curve case, we have already known the result. Assume for dimension ≤n−1\leq n-1≤n−1. Note that the group Div(X)Div(X)Div(X) is generated by very ample divisors (by Serre vanishing, any divisor DDD and ample divisor A′A'A′, D+mA′D+mA'D+mA′ is globally generated and D+mA′+A′D+mA'+A'D+mA′+A′ is very ample.) We may write D=A−BD=A-BD=A−B, we have an exact sequence

0→OX(mD−B)→OX((m+1)D)→OA((m+1)D)→00\to \mathcal{O}_{X}(mD-B)\to \mathcal{O}_{X}((m+1)D)\to \mathcal{O}_{A}((m+1)D)\to 00→OX​(mD−B)→OX​((m+1)D)→OA​((m+1)D)→0

and

0→OX(mD−B)→OX(mD)→OB(mD)→0.0\to \mathcal{O}_{X}(mD-B)\to \mathcal{O}_{X}(mD)\to \mathcal{O}_{B}(mD)\to 0.0→OX​(mD−B)→OX​(mD)→OB​(mD)→0.

By induction hypothesis, OA(D)\mathcal{O}_{A}(D)OA​(D) and OB(D)\mathcal{O}_{B}(D)OB​(D) are all ample. For mmm large,

Hi(OX(mD))→Hi(OX(mD−B))=Hi(OX((m+1)D))H^{i}(\mathcal{O}_{X}(mD))\to H^{i}(\mathcal{O}_{X}(mD-B))=H^{i}(\mathcal{O}_{X}((m+1)D))Hi(OX​(mD))→Hi(OX​(mD−B))=Hi(OX​((m+1)D))

for i≥2i\geq 2i≥2. So χ(OX(mD))=h0(OX(mD))−h1(OX(mD))+C\chi(\mathcal{O}_{X}(mD))=h^{0}(\mathcal{O}_{X}(mD))-h^{1}(\mathcal{O}_{X}(mD))+Cχ(OX​(mD))=h0(OX​(mD))−h1(OX​(mD))+C for some constant CCC when m≫0m\gg 0m≫0. By Theorem 17, for large mmm we have H0(OX(mD))≠0H^{0}(\mathcal{O}_{X}(mD))\neq 0H0(OX​(mD))=0. Replacing DDD by mDmDmD, we may assume DDD is effective.

Consider the exact sequence

0→OX((m−1)D)→OX(mD)→OD(mD)→0,0\to \mathcal{O}_{X}((m-1)D)\to \mathcal{O}_{X}(mD)\to \mathcal{O}_{D}(mD)\to 0,0→OX​((m−1)D)→OX​(mD)→OD​(mD)→0,

OX(D)\mathcal{O}_{X}(D)OX​(D) is ample by induction. It follows that for m≫0m\gg 0m≫0, H1(OX((m−1)D))→H1(OX(mD))H^{1}(\mathcal{O}_{X}((m-1)D))\to H^{1}(\mathcal{O}_{X}(mD))H1(OX​((m−1)D))→H1(OX​(mD)) is surjective and will eventually become isomorphism due to the dimension. Therefore the map H0(OX(mD))→H0(OD(mD))H^{0}(\mathcal{O}_{X}(mD))\to H^{0}(\mathcal{O}_{D}(mD))H0(OX​(mD))→H0(OD​(mD)) is surjective for mmm large. Since OD(mD)\mathcal{O}_{D}(mD)OD​(mD) is base point free, the restriction of elements in ∣mD∣\left| mD \right|∣mD∣ to SuppD\mathop{\mathrm{Supp}}DSuppD do not share a base point. Since OX(mD)\mathcal{O}_{X}(mD)OX​(mD) is base point free from SuppD\mathop{\mathrm{Supp}}DSuppD, we conclude that OX(mD)\mathcal{O}_{X}(mD)OX​(mD) is globally generated. Apply Corollary 26, we get
OX(mD)\mathcal{O}_{X}(mD)OX​(mD) is ample. ◻

Definition 41 (Q\mathbb{Q}Q and R\mathbb{R}R-divisors). We say DDD is a Q\mathbb{Q}Q-divisor if DDD is a finite sum ∑aiAi\sum a_{i}A_{i}∑ai​Ai​, where ai∈Qa_{i}\in \mathbb{Q}ai​∈Q and Ai∈Div(X)A_{i}\in Div(X)Ai​∈Div(X). The set of Q\mathbb{Q}Q-divisors is denoted by Div(X)Q=Div(X)⊗QDiv(X)_{\mathbb{Q}}=Div(X)\otimes\mathbb{Q}Div(X)Q​=Div(X)⊗Q.

We say DDD is an R\mathbb{R}R-divisor if DDD is a finite sum ∑aiAi\sum a_{i}A_{i}∑ai​Ai​, where ai∈Ra_{i}\in \mathbb{R}ai​∈R and Ai∈Div(X)A_{i}\in Div(X)Ai​∈Div(X). The set of R\mathbb{R}R-divisors is denoted by Div(X)R=Div(X)⊗RDiv(X)_{\mathbb{R}}=Div(X)\otimes\mathbb{R}Div(X)R​=Div(X)⊗R.

Similarly we can define the effective Q\mathbb{Q}Q and R\mathbb{R}R-divisors and NQ1(X)N^{1}_{\mathbb{Q}}(X)NQ1​(X), NR1(X)N^{1}_{\mathbb{R}}(X)NR1​(X).

Remark 42. Q\mathbb{Q}Q-divisors D1D_{1}D1​, D2D_{2}D2​ are linearly equivalent if there is an integer rrr such that rD1≡linrD2rD_{1}\equiv_{lin}rD_{2}rD1​≡lin​rD2​, i.e. r(D1−D2)r(D_{1}-D_{2})r(D1​−D2​) is in the image of principal divisors in Div(X)Div(X)Div(X).

Definition 48. Let D=∑aiDiD=\sum a_{i} D_{i}D=∑ai​Di​ be a Q\mathbb{Q}Q(resp. R\mathbb{R}R)-divisor on XXX. The round up ⌈D⌉\lceil D \rceil⌈D⌉ and ⌊D⌋=[D]\lfloor D \rfloor=[D]⌊D⌋=[D] are integer divisors:

Nef Divisors

Definition 49 (Nef Line Bundles and Divisors). Let XXX be a proper scheme. A line bundle L\mathcal{L}L is nef if for every irreducible curve C⊆XC\subseteq XC⊆X, ∫Cc1(L)≥0\int_{C}c_{1}(\mathcal{L})\geq 0∫C​c1​(L)≥0. We say a divisor DDD is nef if OX(D)\mathcal{O}_{X}(D)OX​(D) is nef.

Remark 50. By Chow’s lemma, every proper variety XXX admits a projection model, i.e. a surjective birational morphism μ:X′→X\mu:X'\to Xμ:X′→X such that X′X'X′ is projective, By the projection formula on intersection products, nefness of divisor DDD is equivalent to the nefness of divisor μ∗D\mu^{*}Dμ∗D.

By the similar virtue, we can show:

  1. If f:X→Yf:X\to Yf:X→Y is a proper morphism. L\mathcal{L}L is nef line bundle on YYY, then f∗Lf^{*}\mathcal{L}f∗L is nef on XXX.

  2. If f:X→Yf:X\to Yf:X→Y is a proper surjective morphism. f∗Mf^{*}\mathcal{M}f∗M is nef bundle on XXX, then M\mathcal{M}M is also nef on YYY.

  3. L\mathcal{L}L is nef if and only if Lred\mathcal{L}_{red}Lred​ is nef on XredX_{red}Xred​.

  4. L\mathcal{L}L is nef if and only if the restriction to any irreducible components is nef.

Example 51. Let XXX be a proper variety, D⊆XD\subseteq XD⊆X be a effective divisor. If ND/X=OD(D)\mathcal{N}_{D/X}=\mathcal{O}_{D}(D)ND/X​=OD​(D) is nef, then DDD is nef.

Theorem 52 (Kleiman). Let XXX be a projective scheme. If DDD is nef R\mathbb{R}R-divisor on XXX, then Dk⋅V≥0D^{k}\cdot V\geq 0Dk⋅V≥0 for all V⊆XV\subseteq XV⊆X of dimension kkk.

Proof

Proof. We will do it by induction on dimension of XXX. The base case for XXX which is a curve is clear. So we may assume Dk⋅V≥0D^{k}\cdot V\geq 0Dk⋅V≥0 of rall variety of dimension ≤n−1\leq n-1≤n−1 and show Dn≥0D^{n}\geq 0Dn≥0.

We first show for Q\mathbb{Q}Q-divisor DDD. Take ample divisor HHH on XXX and define $$P(t)=(D+tH)^{n}\in\mathbb{R}.$$ Suppose P(0)<0P(0)<0P(0)<0. Since Hn−kH^{n-k}Hn−k for k<nk<nk<n is effective kkk-cycle, Dn⋅Hn−k≥0D^{n}\cdot H^{n-k}\geq 0Dn⋅Hn−k≥0. So the coefficients of P(t)P(t)P(t) is positive except for the last term. Thus P(t)P(t)P(t) has a single root t0>0t_{0}>0t0​>0. For any t>t0t>t_{0}t>t0​, (D+tH)k⋅V>0(D+tH)^{k}\cdot V>0(D+tH)k⋅V>0 by expanding into intersection terms. So D+tHD+tHD+tH is ample. Let Q(t)=D⋅(D+tH)n−1Q(t)=D\cdot (D+tH)^{n-1}Q(t)=D⋅(D+tH)n−1 and R(t)=tH⋅(D+tH)n−1R(t)=tH\cdot (D+tH)^{n-1}R(t)=tH⋅(D+tH)n−1. For t>t0t>t_{0}t>t0​, D⋅(D+tH)n−1≥0D\cdot (D+tH)^{n-1}\geq 0D⋅(D+tH)n−1≥0 by nefness. Thus by continuity of Q(t)Q(t)Q(t), Q(t0)≥0Q(t_{0})\geq 0Q(t0​)≥0. But R(t0)>0R(t_{0})>0R(t0​)>0 by Nakai criterion for ampleness. Then P(t0)>0P(t_{0})>0P(t0​)>0, contradiction!

Now for any R\mathbb{R}R-divisor DDD, one may choose ample divisor H1,…,HrH_{1},\dots, H_{r}H1​,…,Hr​ spanning N1(X)RN^{1}(X)_{\mathbb{R}}N1(X)R​. Set D(ϵ1,…,ϵr)=D+ϵ1H1+⋯+ϵrHrD(\epsilon_{1},\dots, \epsilon_{r})=D+\epsilon_{1}H_{1}+\cdots+\epsilon_{r}H_{r}D(ϵ1​,…,ϵr​)=D+ϵ1​H1​+⋯+ϵr​Hr​. Then D(ϵ1,…,ϵr)D(\epsilon_{1},\dots, \epsilon_{r})D(ϵ1​,…,ϵr​) is clearly nef by the definition of nefness. We can choose (ϵi)(\epsilon_{i})(ϵi​) such that D(ϵ1,…,ϵr)D(\epsilon_{1},\dots, \epsilon_{r})D(ϵ1​,…,ϵr​) is Q\mathbb{Q}Q-divisor which approaches to DDD. ◻

Corollary 53. Let XXX be a projective variety and DDD be a nef R\mathbb{R}R-divisor on XXX, HHH be an ample R\mathbb{R}R-divisor on XXX. Then D+ϵHD+\epsilon HD+ϵH is ample for all ϵ>0\epsilon>0ϵ>0. Conversely, if DDD and HHH are any two divisors such that D+ϵHD+\epsilon HD+ϵH is ample for all sufficiently small 0<ϵ≪00<\epsilon \ll 00<ϵ≪0, then DDD is nef.

Proof

Proof. If D+ϵHD+\epsilon HD+ϵH is ample then for any effective curve CCC we have (D+ϵH)⋅C>0(D+\epsilon H)\cdot C>0(D+ϵH)⋅C>0. Take ϵ→0\epsilon \to 0ϵ→0 we get D⋅C≥0D\cdot C\geq 0D⋅C≥0, so DDD is nef.

Assume DDD is nef and HHH is ample, it suffices to show D+HD+HD+H is ample. For any subvariety V⊆XV\subseteq XV⊆X of dimension kkk,

(D+H)k⋅V=∑s=0k(ks)(Hs⋅Dk−s⋅V),(D+H)^{k}\cdot V=\sum_{s=0}^{k}\binom{k}{s}(H^{s}\cdot D^{k-s}\cdot V),(D+H)k⋅V=s=0∑k​(sk​)(Hs⋅Dk−s⋅V),

here Hs⋅VH^{s}\cdot VHs⋅V is represented by effective (k−s)(k-s)(k−s)-cycle. So Hs⋅Dk−s⋅V≥0H^{s}\cdot D^{k-s}\cdot V\geq 0Hs⋅Dk−s⋅V≥0. However, Hk⋅V>0H^{k}\cdot V>0Hk⋅V>0, thus (D+H)k⋅V>0(D+H)^{k}\cdot V>0(D+H)k⋅V>0. Then we have done the proof for Q\mathbb{Q}Q-divisors by Nakai criterion. For R\mathbb{R}R-divisors, one can argue similar to the proof of Kleiman’s theorem. ◻

Example 54. Let δ1,…,δn∈N1(X)R\delta_{1},\dots,\delta_{n}\in N^{1}(X)_{\mathbb{R}}δ1​,…,δn​∈N1(X)R​ be nef classes on projective variety XXX. Then δ1⋯δn≥0\delta_{1}\cdots \delta_{n}\geq 0δ1​⋯δn​≥0.

Example 59. We say a surface XXX is minimal if it does not contain any rational curve CCC whose self intersection C2=−1C^{2}=-1C2=−1. Assume XXX is smooth projective variety with κ(X)≥0\kappa(X)\geq 0κ(X)≥0. Then XXX is minimal if and only if KXK_{X}KX​ is nef.

Definition 60. The ample cone Amp(X)⊆N1(X)RAmp(X)\subseteq N^{1}(X)_{\mathbb{R}}Amp(X)⊆N1(X)R​ is the convex cone of all ample R\mathbb{R}R-divisor classes of XXX. Theorem 61. Nef(X)⊆Amp‾(X)Nef(X)\subseteq \overline{Amp}(X)Nef(X)⊆Amp​(X) and Amp(X)=int(Nef(X))Amp(X)=int(Nef(X))Amp(X)=int(Nef(X)).

Proof

Proof. Clearly Amp(X)Amp(X)Amp(X) is open and Nef(X)Nef(X)Nef(X) is closed. We have already known that Amp‾(X)⊆Nef(X)\overline{Amp}(X)\subseteq Nef(X)Amp​(X)⊆Nef(X) and Amp(X)⊆int(Nef(X))Amp(X)\subseteq int(Nef(X))Amp(X)⊆int(Nef(X)).

For DDD lies in int(Nef(X))int(Nef(X))int(Nef(X)), D−ϵHD-\epsilon HD−ϵH is still nef for ϵ≪1\epsilon \ll 1ϵ≪1. So D=D−ϵH+ϵHD=D-\epsilon H+\epsilon HD=D−ϵH+ϵH is ample and int(Nef(X))⊆Amp(X)int(Nef(X))\subseteq Amp(X)int(Nef(X))⊆Amp(X). ◻

Definition 62. Let XXX be a proper variety. Let Z1(X)RZ_{1}(X)_{\mathbb{R}}Z1​(X)R​ be the R\mathbb{R}R-vector space of all real one-cycles on XXX. An element γ∈Z1(X)R\gamma\in Z_{1}(X)_{\mathbb{R}}γ∈Z1​(X)R​ can be written as γ=∑aiCi\gamma=\sum a_{i}C_{i}γ=∑ai​Ci​ where Ci⊆XC_{i}\subseteq XCi​⊆X are irreducible curves. Two cycles γ1\gamma_{1}γ1​, γ2\gamma_{2}γ2​ are numerically equivalent if D⋅γ1=D⋅γ2D\cdot \gamma_{1}=D\cdot \gamma_{2}D⋅γ1​=D⋅γ2​ for all divisor DDD. We write the space modulo numerical equivalence of one-cycles by N1(X)RN_{1}(X)_{\mathbb{R}}N1​(X)R​.

By construction, there is a perfect pairing N1(X)R×N1(X)R→RN_{1}(X)_{\mathbb{R}}\times N^{1}(X)_{\mathbb{R}}\to \mathbb{R}N1​(X)R​×N1(X)R​→R.

Definition 63. Let XXX be a proper variety. The cone of curves NE(X)⊆N1(X)RNE(X)\subseteq N_{1}(X)_{\mathbb{R}}NE(X)⊆N1​(X)R​ is the cone spanned by all effective one-cycles on XXX.

Definition 67. Let K⊆VK\subseteq VK⊆V be a closed convex cone in a finite dimensional real vector space. An extremal ray rrr is one dimensional subcone such that if v+w∈rv+w\in rv+w∈r, then v,w∈rv,w\in rv,w∈r.

Theorem 68. Let XXX be a projective variety of dimension nnn. Let δ1,…,δn∈N1(X)R\delta_{1},\dots, \delta_{n}\in N^{1}(X)_{\mathbb{R}}δ1​,…,δn​∈N1(X)R​ be nef classed. Then

(δ1⋯δn)n≥(δ1n)⋯(δnn).(\delta_{1}\cdots \delta_{n})^{n}\geq (\delta_{1}^{n})\cdots (\delta_{n}^{n}). (δ1​⋯δn​)n≥(δ1n​)⋯(δnn​).

Proof

Proof. It suffices to prove for δ1,…,δn\delta_{1},\dots, \delta_{n}δ1​,…,δn​ ample classes. Pass to the resolution of singularities, we may assume XXX is smooth. We use induction on dimension of XXX. The surface case is done in Hartshorne Ex V.1.9. Assume the results for dimension ≤n−1\leq n-1≤n−1. For any given ample classes B1,…Bn−1,H∈N1(X)RB_{1},\dots B_{n-1}, H\in N^{1}(X)_{\mathbb{R}}B1​,…Bn−1​,H∈N1(X)R​, we first show the inequality

(B1⋯Bn−1H)n−1≥(B1n−1⋅H)⋯(Bn−1n−1⋅H).(B_{1}\cdots B_{n-1}H)^{n-1}\geq (B_{1}^{n-1}\cdot H)\cdots (B_{n-1}^{n-1}\cdot H).(B1​⋯Bn−1​H)n−1≥(B1n−1​⋅H)⋯(Bn−1n−1​⋅H).

By continuity it suffices to show for B1,…,Bn−1,H∈N1(X)RB_{1},\dots, B_{n-1}, H\in N^{1}(X)_{\mathbb{R}}B1​,…,Bn−1​,H∈N1(X)R​ are all very ample integer divisors. By moving lemma, we can assume HHH intersect with BiB_{i}Bi​ transversally. Let Bi‾\overline{B_{i}}Bi​​ be the restriction of BiB_{i}Bi​ to HHH, then the inequality becomes

(B1‾⋯Bn−1‾)n−1≥(B1‾n−1)⋯(Bn−1‾n−1)(\overline{B_{1}}\cdots \overline{B_{n-1}})^{n-1}\geq (\overline{B_{1}}^{n-1})\cdots (\overline{B_{n-1}}^{n-1})(B1​​⋯Bn−1​​)n−1≥(B1​​n−1)⋯(Bn−1​​n−1)

on HHH, which is true by induction hypothesis.

Next we show the original inequality. Let δ1,…,δn∈N1(X)R\delta_{1},\dots, \delta_{n}\in N^{1}(X)_{\mathbb{R}}δ1​,…,δn​∈N1(X)R​ be ample classes. Fix index j∈{1,…,n}j\in\{1,\dots, n\}j∈{1,…,n} and apply above inequality, we have

(δ1⋯δn)n−1≥∏i≠j(δin−1⋅δj).(\delta_{1}\cdots \delta_{n})^{n-1}\geq \prod_{i\neq j}(\delta_{i}^{n-1}\cdot \delta_{j}).(δ1​⋯δn​)n−1≥i=j∏​(δin−1​⋅δj​).

By above inequality again (with H=B1=⋯=Bn−2=δiH=B_{1}=\cdots =B_{n-2}=\delta_{i}H=B1​=⋯=Bn−2​=δi​ and Bn−1=δjB_{n-1}=\delta_{j}Bn−1​=δj​),

(δ1n−1⋅δj)n−1≥(δin)n−2(δi⋅δjn−1).(\delta_{1}^{n-1}\cdot \delta_{j})^{n-1}\geq (\delta_{i}^{n})^{n-2}(\delta_{i}\cdot \delta_{j}^{n-1}).(δ1n−1​⋅δj​)n−1≥(δin​)n−2(δi​⋅δjn−1​).

Thus

∏j∏i≠j(δin−1δj)n−1≥∏j∏i≠j(δin)n−2(δi⋅δjn−1)=(∏i(δin)(n−1)(n−2))(∏j∏i≠j(δj⋅δin−1)),\prod_{j}\prod_{i\neq j}(\delta_{i}^{n-1}\delta_{j})^{n-1}\geq \prod_{j}\prod_{i\neq j}(\delta_{i}^{n})^{n-2}(\delta_{i}\cdot \delta_{j}^{n-1})=(\prod_{i}(\delta_{i}^{n})^{(n-1)(n-2)})(\prod_{j}\prod_{i\neq j}(\delta_{j}\cdot \delta_{i}^{n-1})),j∏​i=j∏​(δin−1​δj​)n−1≥j∏​i=j∏​(δin​)n−2(δi​⋅δjn−1​)=(i∏​(δin​)(n−1)(n−2))(j∏​i=j∏​(δj​⋅δin−1​)),

cancel ∏j∏i≠j(δj⋅δin−1)\prod\limits_{j}\prod\limits_{i\neq j}(\delta_{j}\cdot \delta_{i}^{n-1})j∏​i=j∏​(δj​⋅δin−1​) and take the n−2n-2n−2-th root we get the desired inequality. ◻

Corollary 69. Let XXX be an projective variety of dimension nnn, and fix an integer 0≤p≤n0 \leq p \leq n0≤p≤n. Let α1,…,αp,β1,…,βn−p∈N1(X)R\alpha_{1},\dots, \alpha_{p},\beta_{1},\dots, \beta_{n-p}\in N^{1}(X)_{\mathbb{R}}α1​,…,αp​,β1​,…,βn−p​∈N1(X)R​ be nef classes. Then

By the inclusion of global sections, the morphism ϕm\phi_{m}ϕm​ factors as a composition of ϕkm\phi_{km}ϕkm​ and a linear projection pik:Ykm→Ympi_{k}:Y_{km}\to Y_{m}pik​:Ykm​→Ym​, i.e. ϕm=πk∘ϕkm\phi_{m}=\pi_{k}\circ \phi_{km}ϕm​=πk​∘ϕkm​. Let Mm\mathcal{M}_{m}Mm​ be the very ample line bundle given by the embedding into P(H0(Lm))\mathbb{P}(H^{0}(\mathcal{L}^{m}))P(H0(Lm)), then ϕm∗Mm=Lm\phi_{m}^{*}\mathcal{M}_{m}=\mathcal{L}^{m}ϕm∗​Mm​=Lm.

Lemma 83. *For m∈M(L)m\in M(\mathcal{L})m∈M(L) and k≫0k\gg 0k≫0, the composition

Proof

So Gk\mathcal{G}^{k}Gk is very ample for some k≫0k\gg 0k≫0.

Theorem 84 (Semiample Fibration). There is a fibre space ϕ:X→Y\phi:X\to Yϕ:X→Y such that for any sufficiently large m∈M(L)m\in M(\mathcal{L})m∈M(L), Ym=YY_{m}=YYm​=Y and ϕm=ϕ\phi_{m}=\phiϕm​=ϕ. Proof

Proof. We may assume f=1f=1f=1 by replacing L\mathcal{L}L with Lf\mathcal{L}^{f}Lf, so every large power of L\mathcal{L}L is globally generated. Take relative prime number ppp and qqq such that ϕp\phi_{p}ϕp​ and ϕq\phi_{q}ϕq​ satisfies Lemma 84, i.e Ykp=YpY_{kp}=Y_{p}Ykp​=Yp​, Ykq=YqY_{kq}=Y_{q}Ykq​=Yq​ and ϕkp=ϕp\phi_{kp}=\phi_{p}ϕkp​=ϕp​, ϕkq=ϕq\phi_{kq}=\phi_{q}ϕkq​=ϕq​ for k≥1k\geq 1k≥1. Then Yp=Ypq=YqY_{p}=Y_{pq}=Y_{q}Yp​=Ypq​=Yq​ and ϕp=ϕq\phi_{p}=\phi_{q}ϕp​=ϕq​, denoting the morphism to be ϕ:X→Y=Ypq\phi:X\to Y=Y_{pq}ϕ:X→Y=Ypq​.

There are line bundles Mp\mathcal{M}_{p}Mp​, Mq\mathcal{M}_{q}Mq​ on YYY such that ϕ∗Mp=Lp\phi^{*}\mathcal{M}_{p}=\mathcal{L}^{p}ϕ∗Mp​=Lp and ϕ∗Mq=Lq\phi^{*}\mathcal{M}_{q}=\mathcal{L}^{q}ϕ∗Mq​=Lq. Since ppp, qqq are relatively prime, one may take M\mathcal{M}M such that M=Mpr⊗Mqs\mathcal{M}=\mathcal{M}_{p}^{r}\otimes \mathcal{M}_{q}^{s}M=Mpr​⊗Mqs​ where rp+sq=1rp+sq=1rp+sq=1. Now we show Ym=YY_{m}=YYm​=Y and ϕm=ϕ\phi_{m}=\phiϕm​=ϕ for large mmm. Write m=cp+dqm=cp+dqm=cp+dq for c,d≥1c,d\geq 1c,d≥1, this can be done when m≫0m\gg 0m≫0. Then ScH0(Y,Mp)⊗SdH0(Y,Mq)S^{c}H^{0}(Y,\mathcal{M}^{p})\otimes S^{d}H^{0}(Y,\mathcal{M}^{q})ScH0(Y,Mp)⊗SdH0(Y,Mq) determines a globally generated subspace of H0(Y,Mcp+dq)=H0(X,Lcp+dq)H^{0}(Y,\mathcal{M}^{cp+dq})=H^{0}(X,\mathcal{L}^{cp+dq})H0(Y,Mcp+dq)=H0(X,Lcp+dq). Then by Lemma 84 again, ϕ\phiϕ factor through ϕcp+dq\phi_{cp+dq}ϕcp+dq​ and a finite morphism. Since ϕ\phiϕ is a fibre space, this implies ϕ=ϕm\phi=\phi_{m}ϕ=ϕm​. ◻

Lemma 85. *Let L\mathcal{L}L be a line bundle generated by global sections on a normal projective variety XXX. For any coherent sheaf F\mathcal{F}F on XXX, there exists a number m0>0m_{0}>0m0​>0 such that

Theorem 86. Let XXX be a normal projective variety and L\mathcal{L}L be a semiample line bundle on XXX. Then L\mathcal{L}L is finitely generated.

Remark 88. If λ:X⇢W\lambda:X\dashrightarrow Wλ:X⇢W is a rational fibre space of normal varieties and if the restriction of L\mathcal{L}L to a very general fibre FFF of λ\lambdaλ has Iitaka dimension 0, then λ\lambdaλ factor through Iitaka fibration of L\mathcal{L}L.

Corollary 89. *Let L\mathcal{L}L be a line bundle on normal projective variety XXX and set κ=κ(L)\kappa =\kappa(\mathcal{L})κ=κ(L). Then there are constants a,A>0a, A>0a,A>0 such that

a⋅mκ≤h0(X,Lm)≤A⋅mκa\cdot m^{\kappa}\leq h^{0}(X,\mathcal{L}^{m})\leq A\cdot m^{\kappa} a⋅mκ≤h0(X,Lm)≤A⋅mκ

for all sufficiently large m∈N(L)m\in N(\mathcal{L})m∈N(L).*

Proof

Proof. We may repalce XXX be X∞X_{\infty}X∞​ and consider the Iitaka fibration ϕ:X→Y\phi:X\to Yϕ:X→Y associate to L\mathcal{L}L. Also, we can reduce to the case that e(L)=1e(\mathcal{L})=1e(L)=1. By resolving the singularities, assume XXX is smooth. By the proof of Theorem 87 we know there is an ample bundle N\mathcal{N}N on YYY and a large positive integer m0m_{0}m0​ such that H0(X∞,L∞m0⊗ϕ∞∗(N∗))≠0H^{0}(X_{\infty},\mathcal{L}_{\infty}^{m_{0}}\otimes \phi_{\infty}^{*}(\mathcal{N}^{*}))\neq 0H0(X∞​,L∞m0​​⊗ϕ∞∗​(N∗))=0. This implies

h0(X,Llm0)≥h0(Y,Nl)=lκκ!∫Yc1(N)κ+O(lκ−1).h^{0}(X,\mathcal{L}^{lm_{0}})\geq h^{0}(Y,\mathcal{N}^{l})=\frac{l^{\kappa}}{\kappa!}\int_{Y}c_{1}(\mathcal{N})^{\kappa}+O(l^{\kappa-1}).h0(X,Llm0​)≥h0(Y,Nl)=κ!lκ​∫Y​c1​(N)κ+O(lκ−1).

Hence for sufficiently large m∈m0Nm\in m_{0}\mathbb{N}m∈m0​N we get b>0b>0b>0 such that

bmκ≤h0(X,Lm).bm^{\kappa}\leq h^{0}(X,\mathcal{L}^{m}).bmκ≤h0(X,Lm).

For general mmm, assume km0≤m<(k+1)m0km_{0}\leq m<(k+1)m_{0}km0​≤m<(k+1)m0​. Since h0(Lm)h^{0}(\mathcal{L}^{m})h0(Lm) is non-decreasing in mmm, we have

for large mmm, we can assume m−m0>m2m-m_{0}>\frac{m}{2}m−m0​>2m​. So a=b2κa=\frac{b}{2^{\kappa}}a=2κb​ satisfies the requirement. We get the lower bound for h0(Lm)h^{0}(\mathcal{L}^{m})h0(Lm).

For the converse, take DDD tobe the effective divisor in ∣L∣\left| \mathcal{L} \right|∣L∣ and set D=D1+D2D=D_{1}+D_{2}D=D1​+D2​, where D1D_{1}D1​ consists of those components of DDD that maps to a proper subvariety of YYY via ϕ\phiϕ, and D2D_{2}D2​ maps onto YYY. Thus every fibre FFF of ϕ\phiϕ meets D2D_{2}D2​ but general fibre is disjoint from D1D_{1}D1​. We claim that

H0(OX(mD1))=H0(OX(mD)).H^{0}(\mathcal{O}_{X}(mD_{1}))=H^{0}(\mathcal{O}_{X}(mD)).H0(OX​(mD1​))=H0(OX​(mD)).

In fact, it is equivalent to show that every divisor in the linear system ∣OX(mD)∣\left| \mathcal{O}_{X}(mD) \right|∣OX​(mD)∣ contains a base divisor mD2mD_{2}mD2​. Suppose on the contrary, then D∣F=D2∣FD|_{F}=D_{2}|_{F}D∣F​=D2​∣F​ and there are at least two linearly independent global sections in H0(F,OF(mD2))H^{0}(F,\mathcal{O}_{F}(mD_{2}))H0(F,OF​(mD2​)) (one is 1 and the other defines mD2mD_{2}mD2​), then h0(F,OF(mD))=h0(F,OF(mD2))≥2h^{0}(F,\mathcal{O}_{F}(mD))=h^{0}(F,\mathcal{O}_{F}(mD_{2}))\geq 2h0(F,OF​(mD))=h0(F,OF​(mD2​))≥2. But this contradicts to the fact that κ(L∣F)=0\kappa(\mathcal{L}|_{F})=0κ(L∣F​)=0 for general FFF.

We can find ample divisor HHH such that HHH contains schematic image of D1D_{1}D1​. Then one have

h0(X,OX(mD))=h0(X,OX(mD1))≤h0(X,ϕ∗OY(mH))=h0(Y,OY(mH)).h^{0}(X,\mathcal{O}_{X}(mD))=h^{0}(X,\mathcal{O}_{X}(mD_{1}))\leq h^{0}(X,\phi^{*}\mathcal{O}_{Y}(mH))=h^{0}(Y,\mathcal{O}_{Y}(mH)).h0(X,OX​(mD))=h0(X,OX​(mD1​))≤h0(X,ϕ∗OY​(mH))=h0(Y,OY​(mH)).

The result follows from Theorem 17 on YYY. ◻

Theorem 90. Let L\mathcal{L}L be a line bundle on a normal projective variety XXX such that κ(L)≥0\kappa(\mathcal{L})\geq 0κ(L)≥0. Then κ(L)=dim⁡R(L)−1\kappa(\mathcal{L})=\dim R(\mathcal{L})-1κ(L)=dimR(L)−1.

Proof

Therefore one can embed the fractional field FracR(L)\mathop{\mathrm{Frac}}R(\mathcal{L})FracR(L) into K(X)(s~)K(X)(\tilde{s})K(X)(s~), where s~\tilde{s}s~ is the image of sss. Thus R(L)R(\mathcal{L})R(L) is finite dimensional.

Assume FracR(L)\mathop{\mathrm{Frac}}R(\mathcal{L})FracR(L) is generated by sections si∈H0(Lmi)s_{i}\in H^{0}(\mathcal{L}^{m_{i}})si​∈H0(Lmi​), take nnn to be the least common multiple of mim_{i}mi​s, then R(L)R(\mathcal{L})R(L) is finite over the subring SnS^{n}Sn generated by H0(Ln)H^{0}(\mathcal{L}^{n})H0(Ln). So dim⁡R(L)\dim R(\mathcal{L})dimR(L) is equal to maixmal dimension of subring generated by H0(Lm)H^{0}(\mathcal{L}^{m})H0(Lm). Consider the Veronese subring R(m)=⊕kH0(Lmk)R^{(m)}=\oplus_{k}H^{0}(\mathcal{L}^{mk})R(m)=⊕k​H0(Lmk), then the ideal sheaf defining the schematic image of ϕm\phi_{m}ϕm​ is Im=ker(SymH0(Lm)→R(m))\mathcal{I}_{m}=\mathop{\mathrm{ker}}(\mathop{\mathrm{Sym}}H^{0}(\mathcal{L}^{m})\to R^{(m)})Im​=ker(SymH0(Lm)→R(m)). Then SymH0(Lm)/Im≅Sm\mathop{\mathrm{Sym}}H^{0}(\mathcal{L}^{m})/\mathcal{I}_{m}\cong S^{m}SymH0(Lm)/Im​≅Sm and therefore dim⁡imϕm(X)‾=dim⁡Sm−1\dim \overline{\mathop{\mathrm{im}}\phi_{m}(X)}=\dim S^{m}-1dimimϕm​(X)​=dimSm−1 and κ(L)=dim⁡R(L)−1\kappa(\mathcal{L})=\dim R(\mathcal{L})-1κ(L)=dimR(L)−1. ◻

Big Line Bundles and Divisors

Definition 92 (Big Line Bundles). A line bundle L\mathcal{L}L on projective variety XXX is big if κ(L)=dim⁡X\kappa(\mathcal{L})=\dim Xκ(L)=dimX.

Example 93. Let f:X→Yf:X\to Yf:X→Y be a generically finite morphism of normal projective varieties. L\mathcal{L}L is an ample bundle on YYY. Then f∗Lf^{*}\mathcal{L}f∗L is a big bundle.

Restricting L\mathcal{L}L to an open set UUU is also ample. Shrink UUU if necessary to make f∣f−1(U)f|_{f^{-1}(U)}f∣f−1(U)​ finite, then f∗L∣Uf^{*}\mathcal{L}|_{U}f∗L∣U​ is ample so

κ(f∗L∣U)=dim⁡f−1(U)=dim⁡X.\kappa(f^{*}\mathcal{L}|_{U})=\dim f^{-1}(U)=\dim X. κ(f∗L∣U​)=dimf−1(U)=dimX.

Lemma 94. Assume XXX is projective variety of dimension nnn (unnecessarily normal). A divisor DDD on XXX is big if and only if there exists C>0C>0C>0 such that h0(OX(mD))≥C⋅mnh^{0}(\mathcal{O}_{X}(mD))\geq C\cdot m^{n}h0(OX​(mD))≥C⋅mn for all large m∈N(D)m\in N(D)m∈N(D).

Proof

Proof. Pass to its normalization. ◻

Proposition 95 (Kodaira lemma). Let DDD be a big divisor and EEE an arbitary effective divisor on XXX. Then H0(OX(mD−E))≠0H^{0}(\mathcal{O}_{X}(mD-E))\neq 0H0(OX​(mD−E))=0 for all large m∈N(D)m\in N(D)m∈N(D).

Proof

Proof. Assume dim⁡X=n\dim X=ndimX=n. Consider the exact sequence

0→OX(mD−E)→OX(mD)→OE(mD)→00\to \mathcal{O}_{X}(mD-E)\to \mathcal{O}_{X}(mD)\to \mathcal{O}_{E}(mD)\to 00→OX​(mD−E)→OX​(mD)→OE​(mD)→0

we have h0(OE(mD))≤O(mdim⁡E)h^{0}(\mathcal{O}_{E}(mD))\leq O(m^{\dim E})h0(OE​(mD))≤O(mdimE). Since h0(OX(mD))≤h0(OE(mD))+h0(OX(mD−E))h^{0}(\mathcal{O}_{X}(mD))\leq h^{0}(\mathcal{O}_{E}(mD))+h^{0}(\mathcal{O}_{X}(mD-E))h0(OX​(mD))≤h0(OE​(mD))+h0(OX​(mD−E)), we know that H0(OX(mD−E))≠0H^{0}(\mathcal{O}_{X}(mD-E))\neq 0H0(OX​(mD−E))=0. ◻

Corollary 96. Let DDD be a divisor on a projective variety XXX. Then the followings are equivalent.

  1. DDD is big.

  2. For any ample Cartier divisor AAA on XXX, there exists a positive integer m>0m>0m>0 and an effective divisor NNN on XXX such that mD=linA+NmD=_{lin}A+NmD=lin​A+N.

  3. There exists a ample Cartier divisor AAA, a positive integer m>0m>0m>0 and an effective divisor NNN on XXX such that mD=linA+NmD=_{lin}A+NmD=lin​A+N.

  4. There exists a ample Cartier divisor AAA, a positive integer m>0m>0m>0 and an effective divisor NNN on XXX such that mD=numA+NmD=_{num}A+NmD=num​A+N.

Proof

Proof. For 1. implies 2. One may take rrr large enough such that rArArA and (r−1)A(r-1)A(r−1)A are both effective. Then apply above proposition there is N′N'N′ such that mD=(r+1)A+N′mD=(r+1)A+N'mD=(r+1)A+N′ for m≫0m\gg0m≫0.

For 4. implies 1. Since mD−N=numAmD-N=_{num}AmD−N=num​A, mD−NmD-NmD−N is ample, some multiple of mD−NmD-NmD−N is very ample. So we may assume mD=H+N′mD=H+N'mD=H+N′ where HHH is very ample. Thus κ(D)≥κ(H)=dim⁡X\kappa(D)\geq \kappa(H)=\dim Xκ(D)≥κ(H)=dimX. So DDD is big.

The other implications are obvious. ◻

Corollary 97. If DDD is big then e(D)=1e(D)=1e(D)=1, i.e. every sufficiently large mmm will make mDmDmD effective.

Proof

Proof. Consider a very ample divisor HHH such that H−D=linEH-D=_{lin}EH−D=lin​E with EEE effective. There exist mmm such that mD=linH+NmD=_{lin}H+NmD=lin​H+N for some effective divisor NNN. Then (m−1)D=E+N(m-1)D=E+N(m−1)D=E+N is also effective.mDmDmD and (m−1)D(m-1)D(m−1)D are both effective implies e(D)=1e(D)=1e(D)=1. ◻

Corollary 98. Let L\mathcal{L}L be a big bundle on XXX. Then there exists a proper closed subset X⊆XX\subseteq XX⊆X such that: if Y⊆XY\subseteq XY⊆X is any subvariety not contained in VVV, then L∣Y\mathcal{L}|_{Y}L∣Y​ is a big line bundle on XXX.

Proof

h0(OX(p(P+D)−N))≤h0(OX(mpD))h^{0}(\mathcal{O}_{X}(p(P+D)-N))\leq h^{0}(\mathcal{O}_{X}(mpD)) h0(OX​(p(P+D)−N))≤h0(OX​(mpD))

Therefore vol(p(D+P)−N)≤vol(pD)=pnvol(D)vol(p(D+P)-N)\leq vol(pD)=p^{n}vol(D)vol(p(D+P)−N)≤vol(pD)=pnvol(D). Since 1pnvol(p(D+P)−N)→vol(D+P)\frac{1}{p^{n}}vol(p(D+P)-N)\to vol(D+P)pn1​vol(p(D+P)−N)→vol(D+P) as p→∞p\to \inftyp→∞, we have vol(D+P)≤vol(D)vol(D+P)\leq vol(D)vol(D+P)≤vol(D). Also, take P=−PP=-PP=−P and apply the same argument we will have vol(D+P)=vol(D)vol(D+P)=vol(D)vol(D+P)=vol(D). ◻

Proposition 115. Let f:X′→Xf:X'\to Xf:X′→X be a birational projective morphism between varieties of dimension nnn. For any Q\mathbb{Q}Q-divisor DDD on XXX, we have volX′(f∗D)=volX(D)vol_{X'}(f^{*}D)=vol_{X}(D)volX′​(f∗D)=volX​(D).

Proof

Proof. We only consider Cartier divisor DDD. Consider the exact
sequence

0→OX→f∗OX′→E→00\to \mathcal{O}_{X}\to f_{*}\mathcal{O}_{X'}\to \mathcal{E}\to 00→OX​→f∗​OX′​→E→0

where E\mathcal{E}E is supported on a scheme of dimension ≤n−1\leq n-1≤n−1. Then

h0(X,OX(mD))≤h0(X′,OX′(mf∗D))≤h0(X,OX(mD))+h0(E(mD))≤h0(X,OX(mD))+O(mn−1)\begin{aligned} h^{0}(X,\mathcal{O}_{X}(mD))&\leq h^{0}(X',\mathcal{O}_{X'}(mf^{*}D))\\&\leq h^{0}(X,\mathcal{O}_{X}(mD))+h^{0}(\mathcal{E}(mD))\\&\leq h^{0}(X,\mathcal{O}_{X}(mD))+O(m^{n-1})\end{aligned}h0(X,OX​(mD))​≤h0(X′,OX′​(mf∗D))≤h0(X,OX​(mD))+h0(E(mD))≤h0(X,OX​(mD))+O(mn−1)​

by projection formula. Thus volX′(f∗D)=vol(D)vol_{X'}(f^{*}D)=vol(D)volX′​(f∗D)=vol(D). ◻

Theorem 116 (Continuity of Volume). Let XXX be a projective variety of dimension nnn. Let ∣∣⋅∣∣||\cdot||∣∣⋅∣∣ be the usual norm on N1(X)RN^{1}(X)_{\mathbb{R}}N1(X)R​. Then there exists a positive number C>0C>0C>0 such that for all a,b∈N1(X)Qa,b\in N^{1}(X)_{\mathbb{Q}}a,b∈N1(X)Q​,

∣vol(a)−vol(b)∣≤C⋅(max⁡(∣∣a∣∣,∣∣b∣∣))n−1⋅∣∣a−b∣∣.\left| vol(a)-vol(b) \right| \leq C\cdot (\max(||a||, ||b||))^{n-1}\cdot ||a-b||. ∣vol(a)−vol(b)∣≤C⋅(max(∣∣a∣∣,∣∣b∣∣))n−1⋅∣∣a−b∣∣.

There is a natural way to define volume on N1(X)RN^{1}(X)_{\mathbb{R}}N1(X)R​ by the continuity of volume.

Kodaira Vanishing Theorem

We begin with some theorems from complex geometry. We will assume GAGA.

Theorem 117 (Lefschetz hyperplane). Let XXX be a smooth complex projective variety of dimension nnn, DDD is an effective divisor on XXX. Then Hi(X,D,Z)=0H^{i}(X,D,\mathbb{Z})=0Hi(X,D,Z)=0 for i<ni<ni<n (in usual topology).

Theorem 118 (Hard Lefschetz). For any Kahler form ω\omegaω on XXX, the kkk-fold iterate Lk:Hn−k(X,C)→Hn+k(X,C)L^{k}:H^{n-k}(X,\mathbb{C})\to H^{n+k}(X,\mathbb{C})Lk:Hn−k(X,C)→Hn+k(X,C) of L=LωL=L_{\omega}L=Lω​ is an isomorphism.

Corollary 119. Let XXX be a smooth projective variety of dimension nnn, DDD is smooth effective ample divisor. Let rp,q:Hq(X,ΩXp)→Hq(D,ΩDp)r_{p,q}:H^{q}(X,\Omega_{X}^{p})\to H^{q}(D,\Omega_{D}^{p})rp,q​:Hq(X,ΩXp​)→Hq(D,ΩDp​) be the restriction. Then rp,qr_{p,q}rp,q​ is bijection if p+q≤n−2p+q\leq n-2p+q≤n−2 and is injection if p+q=n−1p+q=n-1p+q=n−1.

Definition 120 (Simple Normal Crossings). An effective divisor DDD is simple normal corssing if it is locally defined by n−1n-1n−1 coordinate sections.

Example 121. Let XXX be a smooth projective variety and D=∑aiDiD=\sum a_{i}D_{i}D=∑ai​Di​ is a snc Q\mathbb{Q}Q-divisor. Assume E⊆XE\subseteq XE⊆X is a smooth very ample divisor and E+DE+DE+D is snc. Then [D]∣E=[D∣E][D]|_{E}=[D|_{E}][D]∣E​=[D∣E​].

To see so, it suffices to show for a prime divisor DDD such that D+ED+ED+E is nsc, then D∣ED|_{E}D∣E​ is reduced. This is local so assume we are working in affine ambient space. Then by definition the defining section x1x_{1}x1​, x2x_{2}x2​ of DDD, EEE is a regular sequence. D∩ED\cap ED∩E is smooth and the local ring is regular, and thus a domain.

Theorem 122 (Resolution of Singularities). Let XXX be a variety and DDD be an effective Cartier divisor on XXX.

  1. There is a projective birational morphism μ:X′→X\mu:X'\to Xμ:X′→X where XXX is nonsingular and μ\muμ has exceptional locus except(μ)except(\mu)except(μ) and μ∗D+except(μ)\mu^{*}D+except(\mu)μ∗D+except(μ) is a snc.

  2. One can construct X′X'X′ via sequence of blow-ups along smooth centers supported in singular locus of DDD and XXX. In particular, one can assume μ\muμ is an isomorphism on X−(Sing(X)∪Sing(D))X-(\mathop{\mathrm{Sing}}(X)\cup \mathop{\mathrm{Sing}}(D))X−(Sing(X)∪Sing(D)).

Definition 123. A log resolution of linear system ∣V∣⊆H0(X,OX(L))\left| V \right| \subseteq H^{0}(X,\mathcal{O}_{X}(L))∣V∣⊆H0(X,OX​(L)) is a projective birational morphism μ:X′→X\mu:X'\to Xμ:X′→X such that X′X'X′ is nonsingular and

μ∗∣V∣=∣W∣+F\mu^{*}\left| V \right| =\left| W \right| +F μ∗∣V∣=∣W∣+F

where F+except(μ)F+except(\mu)F+except(μ) is snc and ∣W∣⊆H0(X′,OX′(μ∗L−F))\left| W \right| \subseteq H^{0}(X',\mathcal{O}_{X'}(\mu^{*}L-F))∣W∣⊆H0(X′,OX′​(μ∗L−F)) is base point free.

Remark 124. A log resolution of ∣V∣\left| V \right|∣V∣ is the same as log resolution of Bs(∣V∣)Bs(\left| V \right| )Bs(∣V∣).

As the resolution can be constructed using blow-ups, we have the followings:

  1. Let KXK_{X}KX​, KX′K_{X'}KX′​ be the canonical divisors, then μ∗OX′(KX′)=OX(KX)\mu_{*}\mathcal{O}_{X'}(K_{X'})=\mathcal{O}_{X}(K_{X})μ∗​OX′​(KX′​)=OX​(KX​) and Rjμ∗OX′(KX′)=0R^{j}\mu_{*}\mathcal{O}_{X'}(K_{X'})=0Rjμ∗​OX′​(KX′​)=0 for j>0j>0j>0;

For 2. Consider a very ample divisor PPP on X′X'X′. Write P=∑aiDi+bEP=\sum a_{i}D_{i}+bEP=∑ai​Di​+bE where DiD_{i}Di​ are divisors distinct from DiD_{i}Di​. Proposition 126 (Cyclic Covering). Let XXX be a variety and L\mathcal{L}L is a line bundle on XXX. For an integer m≥1m\geq 1m≥1, the section s∈H0(Lm)s\in H^{0}(\mathcal{L}^{m})s∈H0(Lm) defines D⊆XD\subseteq XD⊆X. Then there exists a finite flat morphism π:Y→X\pi:Y\to Xπ:Y→X such that there is a section s′∈H0(π∗L)s'\in H^{0}(\pi^{*}\mathcal{L})s′∈H0(π∗L) with (s′)m=π∗s(s')^{m}=\pi^{*}s(s′)m=π∗s. The divisor D=div(s′)D=div(s')D=div(s′) maps isomorphically to DDD. If DDD is snc and XXX is smooth, then the singularity of YYY lies in the singularity of DDD. In particular, if XXX, DDD is smooth, then we may take YYY and D′D'D′ so.

Proof

Proof. We only give construction of π:Y→X\pi:Y\to Xπ:Y→X, the others are local computations. Consider the bundle map p:L→Xp:L\to Xp:L→X where L=SpecSym(L∗)L=\mathop{\mathrm{Spec}}\mathop{\mathrm{Sym}}(\mathcal{L}^{*})L=SpecSym(L∗). Let TTT be the tautological section of p∗Lp^{*}\mathcal{L}p∗L. Then we take Y⊆LY\subseteq LY⊆L be to the divisor corresponding to the section Tm−p∗s∈H0(p∗Lm)T^{m}-p^{*}s\in H^{0}(p^{*}\mathcal{L}^{m})Tm−p∗s∈H0(p∗Lm). ◻

Corollary 127. In the same setting as above construction,

π∗OY=OX⊕L−1⊕L1−m.\pi_{*}\mathcal{O}_{Y}=\mathcal{O}_{X}\oplus \mathcal{L}^{-1}\oplus \mathcal{L}^{1-m}. π∗​OY​=OX​⊕L−1⊕L1−m.

Proof

Proof. By the definition of LLL, π∗OL=⊕i=10∞L−i\pi_{*}\mathcal{O}_{L}=\oplus_{i=10}^{\infty} \mathcal{L}^{-i}π∗​OL​=⊕i=10∞​L−i. In fact, Tm−p∗s∈H0(L,p∗Lm)T^{m}-p^{*}s\in H^{0}(L,p^{*}\mathcal{L}^{m})Tm−p∗s∈H0(L,p∗Lm) implies p∗(Tm−p∗s)=p∗p∗L−m=⊕i=m∞L−ip_{*}(T^{m}-p^{*}s)=p_{*}p^{*}\mathcal{L}^{-m}=\oplus_{i=m}^{\infty}\mathcal{L}^{-i}p∗​(Tm−p∗s)=p∗​p∗L−m=⊕i=m∞​L−i. Remark 128. If DDD is smooth and ∑Di\sum D_{i}∑Di​ is reduced effective divisor on XXX such that D+∑DiD+\sum D_{i}D+∑Di​ is snc. Then D′+∑π∗DiD'+\sum \pi^{*}D_{i}D′+∑π∗Di​ is also snc.

Theorem 129 (Kawamata Covering). Let XXX be smooth projective variety and D=∑i=1tDiD=\sum\limits_{i=1}^{t}D_{i}D=i=1∑t​Di​ be snc on XXX. Fix integers m1,…,mt>0m_{1}, \dots, m_{t}>0m1​,…,mt​>0, then there exists a smooth variety YYY and a finite flat covering f:Y→Xf:Y\to Xf:Y→X such that f∗D=miDi′f^{*}D=m_{i}D_{i}'f∗D=mi​Di′​ for some smooth Di′D_{i}'Di′​ on YYY. D′=∑i=1tDiD'=\sum\limits_{i=1}^{t}D_{i}D′=i=1∑t​Di​ is also snc.

Proof

Proof. By induction on the components, we may assume m2=⋯mt=1m_{2}=\cdots m_{t}=1m2​=⋯mt​=1. To get the smoothness, take an ample divisor HHH such that m1H−D1m_{1}H-D_{1}m1​H−D1​ is globally generated. Assume dim⁡X=n\dim X=ndimX=n, consider H1,…,Hn+1∈∣m1H−D1∣H_{1},\dots,H_{n+1}\in \left| m_{1}H-D_{1} \right|H1​,…,Hn+1​∈∣m1​H−D1​∣, by Bertini Theorem, we may assume D+∑i=1n+1HiD+\sum\limits_{i=1}^{n+1}H_{i}D+i=1∑n+1​Hi​ is snc. We shall construct sequence of cyclic coverings

Yn+1→fn+1⋯Y1→f1XY_{n+1}\xrightarrow{f_{n+1}}\cdots Y_{1}\xrightarrow{f_{1}}XYn+1​fn+1​​⋯Y1​f1​​X

inductively. Assume Yi−1Y_{i-1}Yi−1​ has been constructed, denote πi:Yi→X\pi_{i}:Y_{i}\to Xπi​:Yi​→X the composition of morphisms. Let fif_{i}fi​ be the m1m_{1}m1​-fold cover of YiY_{i}Yi​ with center πi−1∗(Hi+D)=πi−1∗Hi+m(πi−1∗D1)red\pi_{i-1}^{*}(H_{i}+D)=\pi_{i-1}^{*}H_{i}+m(\pi_{i-1}^{*}D_{1})_{red}πi−1∗​(Hi​+D)=πi−1∗​Hi​+m(πi−1∗​D1​)red​, which is, by our construction, same as m1m_{1}m1​-fold branched at pii−1∗Hipi_{i-1}^{*}H_{i}pii−1∗​Hi​ (if locally πi−1∗Hi=div(h)\pi_{i-1}^{*}H_{i}=div(h)πi−1∗​Hi​=div(h) and πi−1∗D1=div(sm)\pi_{i-1}^{*}D_{1}=div(s^{m})πi−1∗​D1​=div(sm), then the relation tm=smht^{m}=s^{m}htm=smh is equivalent to (t/s)m=h(t/s)^{m}=h(t/s)m=h). Thus YiY_{i}Yi​ is smooth outside the singular locus of Hi∩Hi−1∩⋯∩H1∩DH_{i}\cap H_{i-1}\cap \cdots\cap H_{1}\cap DHi​∩Hi−1​∩⋯∩H1​∩D. So Y=Yn+1Y=Y_{n+1}Y=Yn+1​ is smooth. ◻

Theorem 130 (Bloch-Gieseker Covering). Let XXX be a smooth quasiprojective variety, let M\mathcal{M}M be a line bundle on XXX, and fix a positive integer mmm. Then there exist a smooth variety YYY , a finite surjective morphism f:Y→Xf:Y\to Xf:Y→X, and a line bundle L\mathcal{L}L on YYY such that f∗M=Lmf_{*}\mathcal{M} = \mathcal{L}^{m}f∗​M=Lm. Further, given a snc divisor DDD on XXX, we can arrange that its pullback f∗Df ^{*}Df∗D is a snc on YYY.

Proof

Proof. We may write M\mathcal{M}M be the difference of two globally generated sheaves to assume M\mathcal{M}M is globally generated. Then the theorem is a direct corollary from Theorem 129. ◻

Lemma 131 (Injectivity). Let f:Y→Xf:Y\to Xf:Y→X be a finite surjective morphism of projective varieties. Assume XXX is normal and E\mathcal{E}E is a vector bundle on XXX. THen the natrual homomorphism Hj(X,E)→Hj(Y,f∗E)H^{j}(X,\mathcal{E})\to H^{j}(Y,f^{*}\mathcal{E})Hj(X,E)→Hj(Y,f∗E) is injective.

Proof

Proof. By passing to normalization of YYY we may assume YYY is normal. By projection formula, Hj(Y,f∗E)=Hj(X,f∗OY⊗E)H^{j}(Y,f^{*}\mathcal{E})=H^{j}(X,f_{*}\mathcal{O}_{Y}\otimes \mathcal{E})Hj(Y,f∗E)=Hj(X,f∗​OY​⊗E). Consider the trace map TrK(Y)/K(X)Tr_{K(Y)/K(X)}TrK(Y)/K(X)​, it gives rise to a trace map TrY/X:f∗OY→OXTr_{Y/X}:f_{*}\mathcal{O}_{Y}\to \mathcal{O}_{X}TrY/X​:f∗​OY​→OX​, which splits the natural inclusion OX→f∗OY\mathcal{O}_{X}\to f_{*}\mathcal{O}_{Y}OX​→f∗​OY​ by normality of f∗OYf_{*}\mathcal{O}_{Y}f∗​OY​. Therefore the map E→E⊗f∗OY\mathcal{E}\to \mathcal{E}\otimes f_{*}\mathcal{O}_{Y}E→E⊗f∗​OY​ also splits, and thus Hj(E)H^{j}(\mathcal{E})Hj(E) embeds into Hj(X,f∗OY⊗E)H^{j}(X,f_{*}\mathcal{O}_{Y}\otimes \mathcal{E})Hj(X,f∗​OY​⊗E). ◻

Theorem 132 (Kodaira Vanishing). Let XXX be a smooth projective variety of dimension nnn. Let AAA be an ample divisor on XXX. Then Hi(OX(KX+A))=0H^{i}(\mathcal{O}_{X}(K_{X}+A))=0Hi(OX​(KX​+A))=0 for i>0i>0i>0, or by Serre duality, Hj(OX(−A))=0H^{j}(\mathcal{O}_{X}(-A))=0Hj(OX​(−A))=0 for j<nj<nj<n.

Proof

Proof. Since AAA is ample, we can choose smooth D∈∣mA∣D\in \left| mA \right|D∈∣mA∣ for m≫0m\gg 0m≫0. Let p:Y→Xp:Y\to Xp:Y→X be the mmm-fold cyclic covering branched along DDD. Then there is a smooth ample divisor D′∈f∗OX(A)D'\in f^{*}\mathcal{O}_{X}(A)D′∈f∗OX​(A) such that mD′=f∗DmD'= f^{*}DmD′=f∗D. By Lemma 131, it suffices to show Hj(Y,OY(−D′))=0H^{j}(Y,\mathcal{O}_{Y}(-D'))=0Hj(Y,OY​(−D′))=0 for j<nj<nj<n. By the Hodge decomposition we have Hj(X,OX)→Hj(D,OD)H^{j}(X,\mathcal{O}_{X})\to H^{j}(D,\mathcal{O}_{D})Hj(X,OX​)→Hj(D,OD​) is isomorphism for j≤n−2j\leq n-2j≤n−2 and is injective if j=n−1j=n-1j=n−1. But then taking cohomology to the exact sequence

0→OY(−D′)→OY→OD′→00\to \mathcal{O}_{Y}(-D')\to \mathcal{O}_{Y}\to \mathcal{O}_{D'}\to 00→OY​(−D′)→OY​→OD′​→0

shows that Hj(Y,O(−D′))=0H^{j}(Y,\mathcal{O}(-D'))=0Hj(Y,O(−D′))=0 when j≤n−1j\leq n-1j≤n−1. ◻

Definition 133. Suppose XXX is smooth variety and D⊆XD\subseteq XD⊆X is a smooth divisor (or snc). ΩX1(log⁡D)\Omega_{X}^{1}(\log D)ΩX1​(logD) is the sheaf of 1-forms on XXX with logiarithmic poles along DDD, i.e. if z1,…,znz_{1},\dots, z_{n}z1​,…,zn​ are local coordinates on XXX, with DDD defined by zn=0z_{n}=0zn​=0, then Ω1(log⁡D)\Omega^{1}(\log D)Ω1(logD) is locally generated by dz1,…,dzn−1,dznzndz_{1},\dots, dz_{n-1},\frac{dz_{n}}{z_{n}}dz1​,…,dzn−1​,zn​dzn​​. Denote ΩXp(log⁡D)=∧p(ΩX1(log⁡D))\Omega_{X}^{p}(\log D)=\wedge^{p}(\Omega_{X}^{1}(\log D))ΩXp​(logD)=∧p(ΩX1​(logD)).

Lemma 134. Assume D⊆XD\subseteq XD⊆X is a smooth divisor.

We have exact sequence

0→ΩXp→ΩXp(log⁡D)→resΩDp−1→00\to \Omega_{X}^{p}\to \Omega_{X}^{p}(\log D)\xrightarrow{res}\Omega_{D}^{p-1}\to 0 0→ΩXp​→ΩXp​(logD)res​ΩDp−1​→0

and

0→ΩXp(log⁡D)⊗OX(−D)→ΩXp→ΩDp→0.0\to \Omega_{X}^{p}(\log D)\otimes \mathcal{O}_{X}(-D)\to \Omega_{X}^{p}\to \Omega_{D}^{p}\to 0. 0→ΩXp​(logD)⊗OX​(−D)→ΩXp​→ΩDp​→0.

π:Y→X\pi:Y\to Xπ:Y→X be mmm-fold cyclic covering branched along DDD and D′⊆YD'\subseteq YD′⊆Y is the divisor such that π∗D=mD′\pi^{*}D=mD'π∗D=mD′, then π∗(ΩXp(log⁡D))=ΩYp(log⁡D′)\pi^{*}(\Omega_{X}^{p}(\log D))=\Omega_{Y}^{p}(\log D')π∗(ΩXp​(logD))=ΩYp​(logD′). Here the residue map resresres is defined as follows: For any section φ\varphiφ in (ΩXp(log⁡D))(\Omega_{X}^{p}(\log D))(ΩXp​(logD)), we can write φ=φ1+φ2∧dznzn\varphi=\varphi_{1}+\varphi_{2}\wedge \frac{d z_{n}}{z_{n}}φ=φ1​+φ2​∧zn​dzn​​ where φ1\varphi_{1}φ1​ consists of ppp-froms without dznzn\frac{d z_{n}}{z_{n}}zn​dzn​​ and φ2\varphi_{2}φ2​ is the p−1p-1p−1 forms without dznzn\frac{d z_{n}}{z_{n}}zn​dzn​​. Then res:φ↦φ2∣Dres:\varphi\mapsto \varphi_{2}|_{D}res:φ↦φ2​∣D​.

Proof

Proof. All statements are local so we may assume XXX is affine. Easily we can see that “surjective” part of both exact sequence are true. Sections φ\varphiφ restrict to 0 by the residue map if and only if it is in ΩXp\Omega_{X}^{p}ΩXp​. For sections in ker(ΩXp→ΩDp)\mathop{\mathrm{ker}}(\Omega_{X}^{p}\to \Omega_{D}^{p})ker(ΩXp​→ΩDp​), one easily see that it is of the form zn⋅ΩXp+dzn∧ΩXp−1z_{n}\cdot \Omega_{X}^{p}+dz_{n}\wedge\Omega_{X}^{p-1}zn​⋅ΩXp​+dzn​∧ΩXp−1​, which is exactly ΩX(log⁡D)⊗OX(−D)\Omega_{X}(\log D)\otimes \mathcal{O}_{X}(-D)ΩX​(logD)⊗OX​(−D).

For 2. Assume the local section of D′D'D′ is defined by zn+1z_{n+1}zn+1​ with zn+1m=znz_{n+1}^{m}=z_{n}zn+1m​=zn​. Then

π∗dznzn=dzn+1mzn+1m=mdzn+1zn+1,\pi^{*}\frac{d z_{n}}{z_{n}}=\frac{d z_{n+1}^{m}}{z_{n+1}^{m}}=m\frac{dz_{n+1}}{z_{n+1}},π∗zn​dzn​​=zn+1m​dzn+1m​​=mzn+1​dzn+1​​,

we get the desired isomorphism since the generators are the same. ◻

Theorem 135 (Nakano Vanishing). Let XXX be a smooth projective variety of dimension nnn. Let AAA be an ample divisor on XXX. Then

Hq(ΩXp(A))=0 for p+q>n,H^{q}(\Omega_{X}^{p}(A))=0 \text{ for }p+q>n, Hq(ΩXp​(A))=0 for p+q>n,

or equivalently,

Hs(ΩXr(−A))=0 for r+s<n.H^{s}(\Omega_{X}^{r}(-A))=0 \text{ for }r+s<n. Hs(ΩXr​(−A))=0 for r+s<n.

Proof

Proof. Since AAA is ample there exists m≫0m\gg 0m≫0 and a smooth divisor D∈∣mA∣D\in \left| mA \right|D∈∣mA∣. Use induction on dimension we may assume vanishing for DDD ,i.e.

Hs(D,ΩDr−1(−A))=0 for r−1+s<n−1.H^{s}(D,\Omega_{D}^{r-1}(-A))=0 \text{ for }r-1+s<n-1.Hs(D,ΩDr−1​(−A))=0 for r−1+s<n−1.

Consider the exact sequence

0→ΩXr(−A)→ΩXr(log⁡D)⊗OX(−A)→ΩDr−1(−A)→0,0\to \Omega_{X}^{r}(-A)\to \Omega_{X}^{r}(\log D)\otimes \mathcal{O}_{X}(-A)\to \Omega_{D}^{r-1}(-A)\to 0,0→ΩXr​(−A)→ΩXr​(logD)⊗OX​(−A)→ΩDr−1​(−A)→0,

taking the cohomology, we only need to show Hs(X,ΩXr(log⁡D)⊗O(−A))=0H^{s}(X,\Omega_{X}^{r}(\log D)\otimes \mathcal{O}_{(-A)})=0Hs(X,ΩXr​(logD)⊗O(−A)​)=0 for r+s<nr+s<nr+s<n. Consider the mmm-fold covering π:Y→X\pi:Y\to Xπ:Y→X branched at DDD with π∗D=mD′\pi^{*}D=mD'π∗D=mD′. By Lemma 131, it suffices to show Hs(Y,π∗(ΩXr(log⁡D)⊗(−A)))=Hs(Y,ΩYr(log⁡D′)⊗OY(−D′))=0H^{s}(Y,\pi^{*}(\Omega_{X}^{r}(\log D)\otimes(-A)))=H^{s}(Y,\Omega_{Y}^{r}(\log D')\otimes \mathcal{O}_{Y}(-D'))=0Hs(Y,π∗(ΩXr​(logD)⊗(−A)))=Hs(Y,ΩYr​(logD′)⊗OY​(−D′))=0. Take cohomology to the exact sequence

0→ΩYr(log⁡D′)⊗OY(−D′)→ΩYr→ΩD′r→0,0\to \Omega_{Y}^{r}(\log D')\otimes \mathcal{O}_{Y}(-D')\to \Omega_{Y}^{r}\to \Omega_{D'}^{r}\to 0,0→ΩYr​(logD′)⊗OY​(−D′)→ΩYr​→ΩD′r​→0,

since Hs(Y,ΩYr)→Hs(D′,ΩD′r)H^{s}(Y,\Omega_{Y}^{r})\to H^{s}(D',\Omega_{D'}^{r})Hs(Y,ΩYr​)→Hs(D′,ΩD′r​) is bijection for r+s<nr+s<nr+s<n and is injection for r+s=nr+s=nr+s=n, we get the desired result. ◻

Lemma 136. Let XXX be smooth projective variety of dimension nnn. AAA is an ample divisor and EEE is snc on XXX. Then Hi(OX(KX+A+E))=0H^{i}(\mathcal{O}_{X}(K_{X}+A+E))=0Hi(OX​(KX​+A+E))=0 for i>0i>0i>0 or equivalently, Hj(OX(−A−E))=0H^{j}(\mathcal{O}_{X}(-A-E))=0Hj(OX​(−A−E))=0 for j<nj<nj<n.

Proof

Proof. Write E=∑i=1tEiE=\sum\limits_{i=1}^{t}E_{i}E=i=1∑t​Ei​. We use induction on ttt. Assume for t≤k−1t\leq k-1t≤k−1 is true. Then consider the exact sequence

0→OX(−A−∑i=1tEi)→OX(−A−∑i=1k−1Ei)→OEk(−A−∑i=1k−1Ei)→0.0\to\mathcal{O}_{X}(-A-\sum_{i=1}^{t}E_{i})\to \mathcal{O}_{X}(-A-\sum_{i=1}^{k-1}E_{i})\to \mathcal{O}_{E_{k}}(-A-\sum_{i=1}^{k-1}E_{i})\to 0.0→OX​(−A−i=1∑t​Ei​)→OX​(−A−i=1∑k−1​Ei​)→OEk​​(−A−i=1∑k−1​Ei​)→0.

Note the restriction of ∑i=1k−1Ei\sum\limits_{i=1}^{k-1}E_{i}i=1∑k−1​Ei​ to EkE_{k}Ek​ is still snc, taking the cohomology we get the desired result. ◻

Theorem 137 (Kawamata Viehweg Vanishing). Let XXX be a smooth projective variety of dimension nnn. DDD is nef and big divisor on XXX. Then Hi(OX(KX+D))=0H^{i}(\mathcal{O}_{X}(K_{X}+D))=0Hi(OX​(KX​+D))=0 for i>0i>0i>0 or equivalently, Hj(OX(−D))=0H^{j}(\mathcal{O}_{X}(-D))=0Hj(OX​(−D))=0 for j<nj<nj<n.

Proof

Proof. We may write mD=linH+NmD=_{lin}H+NmD=lin​H+N where HHH is ample and NNN is effective divisor. We first show that we can reduce to the case that NNN has snc support. One can consider the log resolution f:X′→Xf:X'\to Xf:X′→X for any singular divisor NNN. Let f∗N=∑aiFif^{*}N=\sum a_{i}F_{i}f∗N=∑ai​Fi​ where FiF_{i}Fi​ includes all exceptional divisors and ai≥0a_{i}\geq 0ai​≥0. Then for some p≫0p\gg 0p≫0, there exists bi≥0b_{i}\geq 0bi​≥0 such that f∗(pH)−∑biFif^{*}(pH)-\sum b_{i}F_{i}f∗(pH)−∑bi​Fi​ is ample on X′X'X′. Then

f∗(pmD)=linf∗(pH)−∑biFi+∑(pai+bi)Fif^{*}(pmD)=_{lin}f^{*}(pH)-\sum b_{i}F_{i}+\sum(pa_{i}+b_{i})F_{i}f∗(pmD)=lin​f∗(pH)−∑bi​Fi​+∑(pai​+bi​)Fi​

is a sum of ample divisor and an effective divisor with snc support. Since Rjf∗OX′(KX′+f∗D)=0R^{j}f_{*}\mathcal{O}_{X'}(K_{X'}+f^{*}D)=0Rjf∗​OX′​(KX′​+f∗D)=0 by projection formula, we know Hj(X,OX(KX+D))=0H^{j}(X,\mathcal{O}_{X}(K_{X}+D))=0Hj(X,OX​(KX​+D))=0 if Hj(X′,OX′(KX′+f∗D))=0H^{j}(X',\mathcal{O}_{X'}(K_{X'}+f^{*}D))=0Hj(X′,OX′​(KX′​+f∗D))=0 (see Corollary 125). Thus we can reduce to the case that NNN has snc support.

Assume N=∑i=1teiEiN=\sum\limits_{i=1}^{t}e_{i}E_{i}N=i=1∑t​ei​Ei​ with ei>0e_{i}>0ei​>0. Set e∗=e1⋯ete^{*}=e_{1} \cdots e_{t}e∗=e1​⋯et​ and ei∗=e∗eie_{i}^{*}=\frac{e^{*}}{e_{i}}ei∗​=ei​e∗​. Apply Theorem 129, we can construct h:Y→Xh:Y\to Xh:Y→X such that h∗Ei=mei∗Ei′h^{*}E_{i}=me_{i}^{*}E_{i}'h∗Ei​=mei∗​Ei′​ for some Ei′E_{i}'Ei′​. Sete E′=∑Ei′E'=\sum E_{i}'E′=∑Ei′​ , D′=h∗DD'=h^{*}DD′=h∗D and H′=h∗HH'=h^{*}HH′=h∗H, then mD′=linH′+me∗E′mD'=_{lin}H'+me^{*}E'mD′=lin​H′+me∗E′. D′D'D′ is nef and thus H′+m(e∗−1)D′=linme∗(D′−E′)H'+m(e^{*}-1)D'=_{lin}me^{*}(D'-E')H′+m(e∗−1)D′=lin​me∗(D′−E′) is ample. We may write D′=linA′+E′D'=_{lin}A'+E'D′=lin​A′+E′ for some ample divisor A′A'A′, so Hj(OY(−D′))=Hj(OY(−A′−E′))=0H^{j}(\mathcal{O}_{Y}(-D'))=H^{j}(\mathcal{O}_{Y}(-A'-E'))=0Hj(OY​(−D′))=Hj(OY​(−A′−E′))=0 by above lemma. By Lemma 131, we get desired results. ◻

Theorem 138. Let DDD be a nef divisor on a smooth projective variety XXX of dimension nnn. Assume Dn−kHk>0D^{n-k}H^{k}>0Dn−kHk>0 for some kkk and ample divisor HHH. Then Hi(OX(K+D))=0H^{i}(\mathcal{O}_{X}(K+D))=0Hi(OX​(K+D))=0 for i>ki>ki>k.

Proof

Proof. We may assume HHH is smooth very ample divisor and apply the induction on dimension nnn. The base case is from Theorem 137. Take the cohomology to the exact sequence

0→OX(KX+D)→OX(KX+D+H)→OH(KX+D)→0.0\to \mathcal{O}_{X}(K_{X}+D)\to \mathcal{O}_{X}(K_{X}+D+H)\to \mathcal{O}_{H}(K_{X}+D)\to 0.0→OX​(KX​+D)→OX​(KX​+D+H)→OH​(KX​+D)→0.

Then Hi(H,OH(KX+D))=0H^{i}(H,\mathcal{O}_{H}(K_{X}+D))=0Hi(H,OH​(KX​+D))=0 for i>k−1i>k-1i>k−1 by induction hypothesis and Hi(X,OX(KX+D+H))=0H^{i}(X,\mathcal{O}_{X}(K_{X}+D+H))=0Hi(X,OX​(KX​+D+H))=0 by Kodaira vanishing. ◻

Theorem 139 (Kawamata Vanishing Theorem for Q\mathbb{Q}Q-divisors). Let XXX be a smooth projective variety of dimension nnn. Let NNN be an integral divisor on XXX and N=numB+ΔN=_{num}B+\DeltaN=num​B+Δ, where BBB is a big and nef Q\mathbb{Q}Q-divisor, Δ=∑aiΔi\Delta=\sum a_{i}\Delta_{i}Δ=∑ai​Δi​ is a Q\mathbb{Q}Q-divisor with snc support and 0≤ai<10\leq a_{i}<10≤ai​<1 (we call divisors with such coefficients fractional). Then Hi(OX(KX+N))=0H^{i}(\mathcal{O}_{X}(K_{X}+N))=0Hi(OX​(KX​+N))=0 for all i>0i>0i>0, or equivalently, Hj(OX(−N))=0H^{j}(\mathcal{O}_{X}(-N))=0Hj(OX​(−N))=0 for all j<nj<nj<n.

Proof

Proof. We apply induction on the number of fractional terms in Δ\DeltaΔ. The base case followed from Theorem 137. Assume a1=cd≠0a_{1}=\frac{c}{d}\neq 0a1​=dc​=0 for some 0<c<d0<c<d0<c<d. By Lemma 131, we only need to construct a finite moprhism p:X′→Xp:X'\to Xp:X′→X such that X′X'X′ is smooth and Hj(X′,p∗OX(−N))=0H^{j}(X',p^{*}\mathcal{O}_{X}(-N))=0Hj(X′,p∗OX​(−N))=0 for j<nj<nj<n. By Theorem 129, we can construct p:X′→Xp:X'\to Xp:X′→X such that ∑p∗Δi\sum p^{*}\Delta_{i}∑p∗Δi​ is snc and p∗Δ1=lindA′p^{*}\Delta_{1}=_{lin}dA'p∗Δ1​=lin​dA′ for some divisor A′A'A′ on X′X'X′. Denote Δi′=p∗Δi\Delta_{i}'=p^{*}\Delta_{i}Δi′​=p∗Δi​, N′=p∗NN'=p^{*}NN′=p∗N and B′=p∗BB'=p^{*}BB′=p∗B. Consider the cyclic covering q:X′′→X′q:X''\to X'q:X′′→X′ branched at Δ1′\Delta_{1}'Δ1′​ and write Δi′′=q∗Δi′\Delta_{i}''=q^{*}\Delta_{i}'Δi′′​=q∗Δi′​, A′′=q∗A′A''=q^{*}A'A′′=q∗A′, B′′=q∗B′B''=q^{*}B'B′′=q∗B′, N′′=q∗N′N''=q^{*}N'N′′=q∗N′. Then N′′=B′′+cA′′+∑i≥2aiΔi′′N''=B''+cA''+\sum\limits_{i\geq 2}a_{i} \Delta_{i}''N′′=B′′+cA′′+i≥2∑​ai​Δi′′​. Then $$N’‘-cA’‘={num} B’’ +\sum{i\geq 2}a_{i}\Delta_{i}’'$$ and the number of fractional part is reduced. By induction hypothesis, we have Hj(X′′,OX′′(cA′′−N′′))=Hj(X′,q∗OX′′(cA′′−N′′))H^{j}(X'',\mathcal{O}_{X''}(cA''-N''))=H^{j}(X',q_{*}\mathcal{O}_{X''}(cA''-N''))Hj(X′′,OX′′​(cA′′−N′′))=Hj(X′,q∗​OX′′​(cA′′−N′′)). Since q∗X′′=OX′⊕OX′(−A′)⊕⋯⊕OX′(−(1−d)A′)q_{*}\mathcal{X''}=\mathcal{O}_{X'}\oplus\mathcal{O}_{X'}(-A')\oplus \cdots \oplus\mathcal{O}_{X'}(-(1-d)A')q∗​X′′=OX′​⊕OX′​(−A′)⊕⋯⊕OX′​(−(1−d)A′),

q∗OX′′(cA′−N′)=(q∗OX′′)(cA′−N′)=OX′(cA′−N′)⊕⋯⊕OX′((c−d+1)A′−N′),q_{*}\mathcal{O}_{X''}(cA'-N')=(q_{*}\mathcal{O}_{X''})(cA'-N')=\mathcal{O}_{X'}(cA'-N')\oplus \cdots\oplus \mathcal{O}_{X'}((c-d+1)A'-N'),q∗​OX′′​(cA′−N′)=(q∗​OX′′​)(cA′−N′)=OX′​(cA′−N′)⊕⋯⊕OX′​((c−d+1)A′−N′),

note c≤d−1c\leq d-1c≤d−1, so OX′(−N′)\mathcal{O}_{X'}(-N')OX′​(−N′) is a direct summands of q∗OX′′(cA′′−N′′)q_{*}\mathcal{O}_{X''}(cA''-N'')q∗​OX′′​(cA′′−N′′). Thus Hj(X′,OX′)(−N′)=0H^{j}(X',\mathcal{O}_{X'})(-N')=0Hj(X′,OX′​)(−N′)=0. ◻

Corollary 140. Let XXX be a smooth projective variety and BBB be a nef and big Q\mathbb{Q}Q-divisor whose fractional part is snc. Then Hi(X,OX(KX+⌈B⌉))=0H^{i}(X,\mathcal{O}_{X}(K_{X}+\lceil B\rceil ))=0Hi(X,OX​(KX​+⌈B⌉))=0 for all i>0i>0i>0.

Definition 141. Let f:X→Yf:X\to Yf:X→Y be a surjective projective morphism of varieties. We say a Q\mathbb{Q}Q-divisor is fff-nef (resp. fff-big) if the restriction to any fibre of fff is nef (resp. big).

Theorem 142. Let BBB be a Q\mathbb{Q}Q-divisor which is fff-nef and fff-big whose fractional part is snc. Then Hi(X,OX(KX+⌈B⌉))=0H^{i}(X,\mathcal{O}_{X}(K_{X}+\lceil B\rceil))=0Hi(X,OX​(KX​+⌈B⌉))=0 for all i>0i>0i>0.

We also have genenalization to R\mathbb{R}R-divisors:

Theorem 143. Let XXX be a smooth projective variety and EEE be a integral divisor. DDD is effective R\mathbb{R}R-divisor with snc support. Assume E−DE-DE−D is big and nef, then Hi(X,OX(KX+E−[D]))=0H^{i}(X,\mathcal{O}_{X}(K_{X}+E-[D]))=0Hi(X,OX​(KX​+E−[D]))=0 for all i>0i>0i>0.

Theorem 144 (Kollar Injectivity). Let f:X→Yf:X\to Yf:X→Y be a surjective morphism of projective varieties. Assume XXX is smooth and YYY is normal. Consider integral divisors NNN and DDD on XXX such that DDD is effective and f(D)≠Yf(D)\neq Yf(D)=Y. Assume N=numf∗B+ΔN=_{num}f^{*}B+\DeltaN=num​f∗B+Δ where BBB is big and nef Q\mathbb{Q}Q-divisor on YYY. Then for every i>0i>0i>0 the morphism

Hi(OX(KX+N))→⋅DHi(OX(KX+N+D))H^{i}(\mathcal{O}_{X}(K_{X}+N))\xrightarrow{\cdot D}H^{i}(\mathcal{O}_{X}(K_{X}+N+D)) Hi(OX​(KX​+N))⋅D​Hi(OX​(KX​+N+D))

is injective.

Lemma 145. Let f:X→Yf:X\to Yf:X→Y be morphism of projective varieties. Let AAA be ample divisor on YYY and F\mathcal{F}F is coherent on XXX such that Hj(X,F⊗OX()f∗mA)=0H^{j}(X,\mathcal{F}\otimes \mathcal{O}_{X}()f^{*}mA)=0Hj(X,F⊗OX​()f∗mA)=0 for all j>0j>0j>0 and m≫0m \gg 0m≫0. Then Rif∗F=0R^{i}f_{*}\mathcal{F}=0Rif∗​F=0 for all j>0j>0j>0.

Proof

Proof. Take mmm large such that Hi(Y,Rjf∗F⊗OY(mA))=0H^{i}(Y,R^{j}f_{*}\mathcal{F}\otimes \mathcal{O}_{Y}(mA))=0Hi(Y,Rjf∗​F⊗OY​(mA))=0 for all i,j>0i,j>0i,j>0 and Rif∗F⊗OY(mA)R^{i}f_{*}\mathcal{F}\otimes \mathcal{O}_{Y}(mA)Rif∗​F⊗OY​(mA) are all generated by global sections. Then the Leray spectral sequence gives

E2i,j=Hi(Y,Rjf∗F⊗OY(mA))⇒Hi+j(X,F⊗OX(f∗mA)).E_{2}^{i,j}=H^{i}(Y,R^{j}f_{*}\mathcal{F}\otimes \mathcal{O}_{Y}(mA))\Rightarrow H^{i+j}(X,\mathcal{F}\otimes \mathcal{O}_{X}(f^{*}mA)).E2i,j​=Hi(Y,Rjf∗​F⊗OY​(mA))⇒Hi+j(X,F⊗OX​(f∗mA)).

So

H0(Y,Rjf∗F⊗OY(mA))≅Hj(X,F⊗OX(f∗mA)).H^{0}(Y,R^{j}f_{*}\mathcal{F}\otimes \mathcal{O}_{Y}(mA))\cong H^{j}(X,\mathcal{F}\otimes \mathcal{O}_{X}(f^{*}mA)).H0(Y,Rjf∗​F⊗OY​(mA))≅Hj(X,F⊗OX​(f∗mA)).

If Rjf∗F≠0R^{j}f_{*}\mathcal{F}\neq 0Rjf∗​F=0, then Hj(X,F⊗OX(f∗mA))=0H^{j}(X,\mathcal{F}\otimes \mathcal{O}_{X}(f^{*}mA))=0Hj(X,F⊗OX​(f∗mA))=0 contradicts with assumption. ◻

Theorem 146 (Grauert-Riemenschneider Vanishing). Let f:X→Yf:X\to Yf:X→Y be generically finite and surjective projective morphism between varieties. Assume XXX is smoooth. Then Rif∗OX(KX)=0R^{i}f_{*}\mathcal{O}_{X}(K_{X})=0Rif∗​OX​(KX​)=0 for i>0i>0i>0.

Proof

Proof. We may assume YYY is projective. The general case comes from compatify YYY and XXX locally. Let AAA be ample divisor on YYY, then mf∗Amf^{*}Amf∗A is nef and big on XXX. So Hi(OX(KX+f∗mA))=0H^{i}(\mathcal{O}_{X}(K_{X}+f^{*}mA))=0Hi(OX​(KX​+f∗mA))=0 by Theorem 137 and by above lemma Rif∗OX(KX)=0R^{i}f_{*}\mathcal{O}_{X}(K_{X})=0Rif∗​OX​(KX​)=0. ◻

Example 147. Let XXX be a projective variety and μ:X′→X\mu:X'\to Xμ:X′→X be a resolution of singularities. Let KX=μ∗OX′(KX′)\mathcal{K}_{X}=\mu_{*}\mathcal{O}_{X'}(K_{X'})KX​=μ∗​OX′​(KX′​). Then KX\mathcal{K}_{X}KX​ is independent of the choice of resolution. For big and nef divisor DDD, we have Hi(KX(D))=0H^{i}(\mathcal{K}_{X}(D))=0Hi(KX​(D))=0 for all i>0i>0i>0.

To see so, note that any two resolutions can be dominated by the third one. If ν:X′′→X′\nu:X''\to X'ν:X′′→X′ is a projective birational morphism of smooth varieties, then ν∗(OX′′(KX′′))=OX′(KX′)\nu_{*}(\mathcal{O}_{X''}(K_{X''}))=\mathcal{O}_{X'}(K_{X'})ν∗​(OX′′​(KX′′​))=OX′​(KX′​). So we can reduce to a further resolution X′′X''X′′. Since higher direct image Riμ∗OX′(KX+f∗D)R^{i}\mu_{*}\mathcal{O}_{X'}(K_{X}+f^{*}D)Riμ∗​OX′​(KX​+f∗D) vanishes, Hi(X,KX(D))=Hi(X′,OX′(KX′+μ∗D))=0H^{i}(X,\mathcal{K}_{X}(D))=H^{i}(X',\mathcal{O}_{X'}(K_{X'}+\mu^{*}D))=0Hi(X,KX​(D))=Hi(X′,OX′​(KX′​+μ∗D))=0 by Theorem 129.

Example 148. We say a normal variety XXX has rational singularities if there is a resolution μ:X′→X\mu:X'\to Xμ:X′→X such that Riμ∗OX′=0R^{i}\mu_{*}\mathcal{O}_{X'}=0Riμ∗​OX′​=0. If DDD is big and nef divisor on XXX then Hj(X,OX(−D))=0H^{j}(X,\mathcal{O}_{X}(-D))=0Hj(X,OX​(−D))=0 for j<nj<nj<n.

Theorem 149 (Fujita Vanishing). *Let XXX be a projective variety and HHH is an integral divisor on XXX. For any coherent sheaf F\mathcal{F}F on XXX, there is an integer m(F,H)>0m(\mathcal{F},H)>0m(F,H)>0 such that

Hi(X,F⊗OX(mH+D))=0H^{i}(X,\mathcal{F}\otimes\mathcal{O}_{X}(mH+D))=0 Hi(X,F⊗OX​(mH+D))=0

for all i>0i>0i>0, m≥m(F,H)m\geq m(\mathcal{F},H)m≥m(F,H) and any nef divisor DDD.*

Proof

Proof. For any coherent sheaf F\mathcal{F}F, using the resolution one can reduce to show for OX(aH)\mathcal{O}_{X}(aH)OX​(aH). In fact, it suffices to show for a specific aaa. Let μ:X′→X\mu:X'\to Xμ:X′→X be a resolution of singularities and KX=μ∗OX′(KX′)\mathcal{K}_{X}=\mu_{*}\mathcal{O}_{X'}(K_{X'})KX​=μ∗​OX′​(KX′​). For a sufficiently large aaa there is an inejction u:KX→OX(aH)u:\mathcal{K}_{X}\to \mathcal{O}_{X}(aH)u:KX​→OX​(aH). The cokernel cokeru\mathop{\mathrm{coker}}ucokeru is supported on a proper subvariety of XXX, by induction on dimension, we only need to show for KX\mathcal{K}_{X}KX​.

Note Rjμ∗OX′(KX′)=0R^{j}\mu_{*}\mathcal{O}_{X'}(K_{X'})=0Rjμ∗​OX′​(KX′​)=0 for j>0j>0j>0, so

Hi(X,KX⊗OX(aH+D))=Hi(X′,OX′(KX′+μ∗(aH+D)))=0H^{i}(X,\mathcal{K}_{X}\otimes \mathcal{O}_{X}(aH+D))=H^{i}(X',\mathcal{O}_{X'}(K_{X'}+\mu^{*}(aH+D)))=0Hi(X,KX​⊗OX​(aH+D))=Hi(X′,OX′​(KX′​+μ∗(aH+D)))=0

by Theorem 137. ◻

Theorem 150. Let XXX be a projective variety of dimension nnn. DDD is a nef divisor on XXX. Then for any coherent sheaf F\mathcal{F}F on XXX, hi(F(mD))=O(mn−i)h^{i}(\mathcal{F}(mD))=O(m^{n-i})hi(F(mD))=O(mn−i).

Proof

Proof. Use the induction on dimension and consider the exact sequence

0→F(mD)→F(mD+H)→F(mD+h)⊗OH→0.0\to \mathcal{F}(mD)\to \mathcal{F}(mD+H)\to \mathcal{F}(mD+h)\otimes \mathcal{O}_{H}\to 0.0→F(mD)→F(mD+H)→F(mD+h)⊗OH​→0.

◻

Corollary 151. Let XXX be a projective variety of dimension nnn and DDD be a nef divisor on XXX. Then

h0(O(mD))=Dnn!mn+O(mn−1).h^{0}(\mathcal{O}(mD))=\frac{D^{n}}{n!}m^{n}+O(m^{n-1}). h0(O(mD))=n!Dn​mn+O(mn−1).

More generally, for coherent sheaf F\mathcal{F}F on XXX,

h0(F(mD))=rk(F)Dnn!mn+O(mn−1).h^{0}(\mathcal{F}(mD))=\mathop{\mathrm{rk}}(\mathcal{F})\frac{D^{n}}{n!}m^{n}+O(m^{n-1}). h0(F(mD))=rk(F)n!Dn​mn+O(mn−1).
